title: Sergei Eisenstein is born.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is born in Riga in Nikolai Street 6, apartment no. 7.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 11 f.

title: Eisenstein is baptized.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is baptized in Riga Cathedral.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 12

title: Has earliest childhood memories of a summer stay in the country at Riga Bay.
description: Sergei Eisenstein spends the summer at the Riga Bay. He dates his earliest childhood memories back to this stay in the country. "A branch of white lilac, striped by a diagonally falling sunbeam, looks in through the window. Swings above me. My first conscious impression - the close-up." (Stationen. Autobiographische Aufzeichnungen. Ü.: R. Braun. Berlin/DDR 1967., p. 367) In connection with the experience of later reading Edgar Allan Poe's arabesque 'The Sphinx' (1846), he attributes his interest in foreground composition to this fragment of memory.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 13

title: Sees an amateur theatre performance by his relatives.
description: Again Sergei Eisenstein spends the summer in a summer house at the Riga Bay. He sees an amateur performance of 'The Butler Did It'. His relatives stage the play.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 13 f.

title: Witnesses the repression of demonstrators by the tsarist police during the First Russian Revolution.
description: Sergei Eisenstein witnesses the repression of demonstrators by the tsarist police during the First Russian Revolution.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 14

title: Travels to Paris with his parents.
description: Sergei Eisenstein travels to Paris with his parents. They stay at the Hotel Du Helder in Rue du Helder. He has his first cinema going experience. He visits Napoleon's tomb, Notre Dame, the Botanical Garden and the waxworks cabinet in the Musée Grevin. Scenes from the waxwork inspire him while working on the Sergei Tretiakov play 'Can You Hear Me, Moscow?' and his own film 'October'.
keyword: Sergei Tretiakov;Can You Hear Me Moscow?;October;Travels
works: Can You Hear Me٫ Moscow?;October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 15

title: Sergei Eisenstein's parents separate.
description: Sergei Eisenstein's mother Iulia Konetskaia separates from her husband and moves to St. Petersburg to Tavricheskaia street 9. Sergei Eisenstein stays with his father in Riga.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 16

title: Sergei Eisenstein learns English and French.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is learning English and French; since he lives in Riga, he already speaks better German than Russian.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 15

title: Discovers caricatures of André Gill and Honoré Daumier.
description: In his father's library Sergei Eisenstein finds a book entitled 'Das Jahr 1871 und die Pariser Kommune';, in which he discovers caricatures of André Gill and Honoré Daumier, which fascinate him so much that he persuades the housekeeper to buy a Daumier monograph. In a later study of the sensation of a movement sequence, he draws conclusions from Daumier's caricatures about the construction of an artificially generated movement.
category: Graphic Art;Biography and Personality;Writing and Teaching
keyword: The Year 1871 and The Paris Commune;André Gill;Honoré Daumier;Das Jahr 1871 und die Pariser Kommune;Studies
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 15

title: Reads french novels.
description: Sergei Eisenstein reads Victor Hugo's novel 'Les Misérables' (1862); until 1913 novels by Alexandre Dumas père and Émile Zola's novel cycle 'Les Rougon-Macquart' (1871-1893).
keyword: Victor Hugo;Les Misérables;Alexandre Dumas père;Emile Zola;Les Rougon-Macquart
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 15

title: Sergei Eisenstein and Maksim Shtraukh become friends.
description: Beginning of the friendship with Maksim Shtraukh, with whom Sergei Eisenstein later works on many theatre and film productions.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 16

title: Writes and directs his first play.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes and directs his first play based on a Pamphlet brochure against drunkenness.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 16

title: Admitted to the Riga City Real-gymnasium
description: Sergei Eisenstein is admitted to the first class of Riga City Real-gymnasium in autumn.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 16

title: Begins to draw.
description: Inspired by an employee of his father, engineer Afrossimov, Sergei Eisenstein begins to draw "very much and very badly". With time, his interest concentrates on pure line drawing.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 16

title: First visit to a circus performance in St. Petersburg.
description: Sergei Eisenstein for the first time visits a circus performance in St. Petersburg. He soon becomes a passionate follower of the circus. The principle of a program based on numbers determines the structure of his early theatrical productions, which break down each fragment of a play into artistic attractions and work with the eccentric elements of the circus and the Music Hall (clowns, tightrope walkers, acrobats). The structure of a circus performance is at the same time the starting point for the development of the idea of Montage.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 16

title: Intense interest for the French Revolution.
description: Inspired by the reading of French revolutionary novels, Sergei Eisenstein asks for 'Histoire de la Revolution française' by François Auguste Mignet for Christmas.
keyword: Histoire de la Revolution française;François Auguste Mignet
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 17

title: Watches his first colour film.
description: Sergei Eisenstein watches the first "films in natural colours […]."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 17

title: Watching a cruel film scene becomes a traumatic experience.
description: The cruelty of a film scene in which a blacksmith burns a convict's mark on the shoulder of a sergeant in revenge, together with the reading of the novels 'The Torture Garden' (1899) by Octave Mirabeau and 'Venus in Furs' (1870) by Leopold von Sacher-Masoch are a traumatic experience for Sergei Eisenstein, "until the ocean of cruelties that my own films are filled with [...] flooded these early impressions of the disastrous film and the two books that undoubtedly influenced this ocean".
keyword: The Torture Garden;Octave Mirabeau;Venus in Furs;Leopold von Sacher-Masoch
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 17 f.

title: Works at a performance of 'Die Nibelungen'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein prepares the performance of two acts from Friedrich Hebbel's tragedy 'Die Nibelungen' (1862).
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 18

title: Sergei Eisenstein and Maksim Shtraukh organize circus performances.
description: Sergei Eisenstein organizes circus performances with Maksim Shtraukh, where all roles - including the animals - are performed by Shtraukh and Eisenstein.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 18

title: Sergei Eisenstein's enthusiasm for theatre begins.
description: Sergei Eisenstein's enthusiasm for theatre begins when he attends the performance of Carlo Gozzi's tragicomedy 'Turandot' (1762) of the St. Petersburg theatre group K. N. Nezlobin in the production of Fedor Komissarzhevski in Riga.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 18

title: Parents get divorce.
description: The marriage of Sergei Eisenstein's parents is divorced for breach of fidelity by Iulia Konetskaia.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 18

title: Processes politics and his school life in drawings.
description: Sergei Eisenstein draws a lot. Over the years he begins to occupy himself with a series of satirical drawings in his sketch books - 'In the World of Animals' - in which daily political events, personalities of Riga society and school events are processed.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 18

title: Spends the summer with his mother in Staraja Russa.
description: Sergei Eisenstein spends the summer with his mother in Staraja Russa. There he experiences a procession that later inspires him to the church procession in the film 'The General Line'. During the stay he meets Anna Dostoevskaia, the widow and executor of Fedor Dostoevski's estate.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 19

title: Graduation from high school, from which later he remembers his final religion exam especially.
description: Sergei Eisenstein graduates high school. He later describes his final religion exam as the origin of his later atheism.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 19

title: The family is evacuated from Riga due to the war. Sergei Eisenstein travels to Petrograd to enter the Institute of Civil Engineering.
description: Families of officials are evacuated from Riga in anticipation of German troops advancing on Lithuania and Kurland since April 1915. Sergei Eisenstein travels with his father to Petrograd for the entry exam to the Institute of Civil Engineering. During the trip he rebels against his authoritarian father for the first time.
additional: Institute of Civil Engineering;First World War
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 19

title: Starts living in Petrograd.
description: From his entrance exam to the Institute of Civil Engineering on Sergei Eisenstein lives with his mother until 1918.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 19

title: Begins his studies at the Institute of Civil Engineering.
description: Sergei Eisenstein starts his studies at the Institute of Civil Engineering in Petrograd. He is intensively engaged in analytic geometry.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 19

title: Occupation with the art of Italian Renaissance.
description: Sergei Eisenstein occupies himself with the art of Italian Renaissance. The theatrical means of the mask in the Commedia dell'Arte is decisive for the development of the Character Typage in Sergei Eisenstein's films.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 20

title: Visits the Vaudeville Theatres in Petrograd.
description: Sergei Eisenstein visits the Vaudeville Theatres in Petrograd and meets the theatre director Nikolai Evreinov.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 20

title: Becomes a city militiaman.
description: The Institute of Civil Engineering is converted into "a centre for law and order and assigned to the Izmailov regiment". Sergei Eisenstein becomes a city militiaman.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 20

title: Takes the exam in Higher Mathematics.
description: Sergei Eisenstein takes the exam in Higher Mathematics.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 20

title: Visits the repertoire productions of Meyerhold.
description: Sergei Eisenstein visits the repertoire productions of Vsevolod Meyerhold at the Aleksandrinski Theatre: Molière, 'Don Juan' (on the program since November 9, 1910) and Calderón de la Barca, 'The Constant Prince' (on the program since April 23, 1914). The traditional costume, mask and decoration designs from the year 1917 that are preserved in the Sergei Eisenstein Archive may, among other things, be directly related to these theatrical experiences.
keyword: Vsevolod Meyerhold;Aleksandrinski Theatre;Molière;Calderón de la Barca;Constant Prince
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 20

title: Outbreak of the February Revolution in Petrograd.
description: Outbreak of the February Revolution in Petrograd: Troops defect to the insurgents; a provisional executive committee of the Council of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies is formed. Sergei Eisenstein observes the actions, but never participates actively.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 20

title: Seeing the Meyerhold production of 'Masquerade' has lasting impact on Sergei Eisenstein.
description: Sergei Eisenstein sees the new Meyerhold production 'Masquerade' (1835/36) by Mikhail J. Lermontov at the Aleksandrinski Theatre. He is very impressed and later describes it as the final blow to dedicate his life to art.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 20

title: First caricatures get published in newspapers.
description: Sergei Eisenstein starts professionally drawing caricatures, which are initially rejected by the magazine Satirikon. The editor of the Petrograd Gazette accepts a drawing showing "the police, restoring order" for publication; Sergei Eisenstein receives a fee of 10 rubles. Other caricatures appear with the signature "Sir Gay" (= Sergei).
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 21

title: Begins studying at the School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers
description: Sergei Eisenstein's application for admission to the School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers in Petrograd is accepted. He takes his first courses at the school not later than July.
places: Russian Empire;Russia;St. Petersburg;School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers
additional: School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 21

title: Is caught up in Bolshevik demonstrations at Nevski Prospect.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is caught up in Bolshevik demonstrations at Nevski Prospect, which are dispersed by military intervention. Ten years later, after personal memories and historical film and photo documents, he shoots the film 'October' there.
works: Can You Hear Me٫ Moscow?;October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 21

title: Is sent to the front with the School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is sent to the front. The School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers is used for defense "in the forecourt of Petrograd in front of the "anrückenden Haufen Kornilovs und der 'wilden Division'«.
additional: School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers;First World War;February Revolution
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 21

title: Scene sketches for Carlo Goldoni 'The Honorable Maid'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein drafts two scene sketches for Carlo Goldoni 'The Honorable Maid'.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 21

title: First thoughts on the principle of counterpoint.
description: In autumn while practicing building pontoon bridges, Sergei Eisenstein has his first insights concerning the principle of counterpoint "as a strictly limited combination of countless independent individual actions".
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 21

title: Reads Albrecht Dürer's 'Diary of his journey to the Netherlands'.
description: In autumn Sergei Eisenstein reads Albrecht Dürer's 'Diary of his journey to the Netherlands'.
keyword: Studying;Albrecht Dürer;Diary of his journey to the Netherlands
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 21

title: Works on an own pantomime, 'Les Millions de Pierrot.
description: Sergei Eisenstein designs a libretto and figurines for a pantomime, presumably written by himself, under the title 'Les Millions de Pierrot'.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 21

title: Creates caricatures on the October Revolution, that are rejected.
description: October Revolution in Petrograd. Sergei Eisenstein offers caricatures about the Prime Minister, Aleksandr Kerenski, to Stanislav Propper, the editor of the weekly magazine Ogonek. Propper does not accept the work, but promises him commissions. Sergei Eisenstein receives an advance of 25 rubles.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 22

title: Sergei Eisenstein creates several designs for costumes, masks and decorations.
description: 1917 Sergei Eisenstein creates designs for costumes, masks and decorations for Shakespeare's 'Hamlet' (1600), decoration designs for Gerhart Hauptmann, 'The Weavers' (1892) and the comedy 'Schluck und Jau' (1900), costume designs for the prose comedy of Molière, 'Scapin the Schemer', decoration and Costume designs for a vaudeville (author not identified) 'First Die and Then You Can Be Honored' as well as for 'Queen of Spades' after Aleksandr Pushkin or Petr Tchaikovski.
keyword: Shakespeare;Hamlet;Gerhart Hauptmann;The Weavers;Schluck und Jau;Molière;Scapin the Schemer;End well all is well;Queen of spades;Aleksandr Pushkin;Petr Tchaikovski;Comedy

source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 22

title: Sergei Eisenstein writes several plays and stage drafts.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes the farce in one act 'Spießbürger', the drama 'Dawn of the Red Alarm', the "Mystery Play in six pictures with prologue" 'Evolution of a Witch' and presumably the pantomime 'Four Harlekins', which was preserved in the archive. Drafts for the production of all pieces are created.
keyword: Spießbürger;The fire of the red storm;The Evolution of the Witch;Pantomime;The Four Harlequins
works: Dawn of the Red Alarm;Evolution of a Witch;Four Harlekins
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 22

title: Sergei Eisenstein works further on dramatizations and theatre designs.
description: In 1917 or 1918, Sergei Eisenstein works on decoration, costumes and and mask designs for fairy tale plays by Carlo Gozzi, 'The Love of the Three Oranges', 'The Serpent Woman' and 'The Green Bird'. He writes "dramatic scenes after the Memoirs of Achilleus", 'Achilliada', and dramatizes Persian fairy tales.

keyword: Costume Design;The love of the three oranges;The serpent woman;The Green Bird;Achilliada;Fairy Tales

title: Returns to Institute of Civil Engineering.
description: The School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers is closed. Sergei Eisenstein returns to his studies of Civil Engineering.

title: Joins the Red Army.
description: Voluntary entry into the Red Army as an engineer for military structures in the 2nd Sappers of the Petrograd rayon, the later 18th Sappers in the 15th Armed Forces Staff. Sergei Eisenstein's father decides to join the White Army at the same time.

description: The 18th Sappers are transferred to the northeastern front. There Sergei Eisenstein makes the acquaintance of Maria Pushkina. "In Eisenstein's diaries one constantly encounters the initials M. P."

title: Experiences a former battlefield when transferred to Dvinsk.
description: Sergei Eisenstein's unit is moved to Dvinsk. He takes part in the blasting of German fortifications on a former battlefield littered with skeletons. Later he uses this image in the prologue of 'Aleksandr Nevski'.

title: Works on designs for 'Queen Theodora'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein works on set, masks and costume designs for 'Queen Theodora'; it is either a vaudeville of Victorien Sardou or a dramatization of his own.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 25

title: Studies the staging principles of medieval mystery plays.
description: Sergei Eisenstein tells his mother that he is working on the staging principles of medieval mystery plays.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 25

title: Envisions images later used in 'The Old and the New'/ 'The General Line'.
description: One summer day after an "unusually luxuriant meal", Sergei Eisenstein falls into a visionary half-sleep; the visions are "a good five years later [...] in my head not yet blurred [...] the kulak’s ear and the crease in his neck, as big as the whole movie screen, the nose of the other one the size of a house, a huge hand, sleepily helpless over a jug of kvass, a grasshopper the size of a mower - such images were incessantly interwoven with the sarabande of landscapes and rural customs in the film 'The Old and the New'." (Stationen, p. 107f.)
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 25

title: Drafts libretto and designs for 'Les douze heures de Colombine'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein drafts a libretto for a pantomime "grand Colombino-Arlequinade" 'Les douze heures de Colombine'; designs for set and figurines are created.
keyword: Set Design;Pantomime;Grand Colombino-Arlequinade;The twelve hours of Columbina
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 25

title: Studies Maeterlinck, Schopenhauer and especially Kleist's work on movement.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is sent to Cholm to build defences. He reads works by Maurice Maeterlinck, Arthur Schopenhauer and the theatre-theoretical writings of Heinrich von Kleist; Kleist's 'On the Marionette Theatre' gives Sergei Eisenstein an initial impetus for later studies of expressive movement, and "the first two or three guiding principles on biomechanics will continue to follow the path taken by Kleist".
keyword: Studying;Maurice Maeterlinck;Arthur Schopenhauer;Heinrich von Kleist;On the Marionette Theatre
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 25/26

title: From the time between 1919 and 1921 several more plays and designs by Sergei Eisenstein are preserved.
description: In 1919, he creates costume and set designs for a Mystery Play by an unidentified author: 'Notre-Dame'; Set designs for 'Bartholomew Fair' (1613) and 'Volpone' (1605) by Ben Jonson, for 'Peer Gynt' (1867) by Henrik Ibsen; figure designs for 'Eric XIV' (1899) by August Strindberg; set, costume and mask designs for the presumably Old French "morality of the two Lazarus'". The dating is uncertain for the sets and costume designs for Gerhart Hauptmann's 'Elga' (1905) and for the comedy 'Nymphs of the Ancient Gardens' , for which costume designs and a cast list has been handed down. The author has not been identified. In 1919 or 1920 Sergei Eisenstein works on drafts for the opera 'Dubrovski' from Eduard Napravnik after a story by Aleksandr Pushkin, on 'A Play about George the Brave' by Vasili Rozanov and the drama 'The King’s Barber' by Anatoli V. Lunacharski; for the drama 'Savva' (1907) by Leonid N. Andreev sketches are created. Between 1919 and 1921, Sergei Eisenstein writes 'Comedy of Power-Queen Isabella', for which, in addition to designs for equipment, stage directions have been handed down. In 1919 or 1921, Sergei Eisenstein works on sets for Vladimir V. Maiakovski's 'Mystery-Bouffe' (1918).

description: The Double', 'The Mirror' and the comedy 'The Lawsuit' by Nikolai V. Gogol are performed at the Cultural Club in Velikie Luki. In 'The Double', Sergei Eisenstein plays the (secondary) role of the bespectacled man. In one criticism it says, "that all the performers (including myself) overacted excessively [...] that they all [...] turned themselves into circus eccentrics!"

title: For the performance of 'The Mexican' Sergei Eisenstein works not only as Set Designer but also Co-Director for the first time.
description: Together with Leonid Nikitin, Sergei Eisenstein begins designing the set, scenery and masks for 'The Mexican' by Jack London, dramatized by Boris Arvatov, Valentin Smishliaevand Eisenstein. Sergei Eisenstein writes most notably the interludes. He advances from Set Designer to Co-Director: At his suggestion, the boxing match - a key scene - is performed directly on stage and is not transmitted to the spectators through a wall show.

title: The independence of Proletkult from state and party is abandoned.
description: The CC of the RKP(b) (Central Committee of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)) and, on its instructions, the Communist faction of the last All-Russian Proletkult Congress decides to subordinate the Proletkult Organizations to the People's Commissariat of Education with the rank of a department. Thus the hard-defended independence of the Proletkult from the state and party is abandoned.

title: Registers for the entrance exams at the GVYTM
description: Sergei Eisenstein registers for the entrance exams at the GVYTM (State Higher Theatre Workshops) under the direction of Vsevolod Meyerhold. There he meets Sergei Iutkevich for the first time. Both are given the task of developing a scenic solution to the topic 'Sechs verfolgen einen' and pantomime the shooting with an imaginary bow. Under Meyerhold's influence, Sergei Eisenstein receives further impetus for his conception of an acrobatic, non-naturalistic theatre with political objectives. Sergei Eisenstein worshipped Meyerhold until his death, speaks of him with the greatest admiration and calls him his "second father".
places: Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic;Russia;Moscow;GVYRM (State Higher Directors' Workshops)
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 33 f.

title: Works on several more pieces in 1921 and 1922.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is working on a piece of an unidentified author, 'Honest Harlequin'. In 1921/22, as a study for the GVYTM, he works on the creation of a scenic montage, 'The Count of Monte Cristo', based on the novel by Alexandre Dumas père, which is commissioned by Valeri M. Bebutov. In 1921 or 1922, he also produces sketches and drafts for a dramatization of the E.T.A. Hoffmann novella 'Master Martin, the Cooper, and His Journeyman'.

title: Writes his first essay on film theory.
description: With Sergei Iutkevich, Sergei Eisenstein writes his first essay on Film Theory: 'The eighth art. About Expressionism, America and, of course, Charlie Chaplin'. In this essay, Sergei Eisenstein examines the anti-illusionist tendencies of European and American film production and lists as examples almost everything that shows the approach to eccentricity: 'The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari', Charlie Chaplin, the abstract film and the American detective and adventure film.

description: Sergei Eisenstein goes to Petrograd with Sergei Iutkevich and there makes the acquaintance of Grigori Kozintsev and Leonid Trauberg, the founders of FEKS (Factory of the Eccentric Actor, an actors' collective founded by Kozintsev and Trauberg in Petrograd on December 9,1921, which published an artistic manifesto entitled 'Eccentrism'.), with whom he is connected by the conception of eccentric forms of expression.

title: Adapts the pantomime 'The Veil of Pierrette' under the title 'The Veil of Columbina' together with Iutkevich.
description: Together with Sergei Iutkevich, Sergei Eisenstein adapts the pantomime 'The Veil of Pierrette' by Ernst von Dohnányi, set to music based on motifs from Arthur Schnitzler's play 'The Veil of Beatrice', and produced by Vsevolod Meyerhold in 1910 under the pseudonym Dr. Dapertutto and in 1916 under the title 'The Scarf of Columbine' in St. Petersburg. Eisenstein and Iutkevich give the new edition for MASTFOR the title 'The Veil of Columbina' and dedicate the adaptation, understood as a parody of Aleksandr Tairov's production of 'The Veil of Pierrette' (1913), to "Vsevolod Meyerhold, master of the scarf - the sub-masters of the garter".

title: Reworking 'The Veil of Columbina' in summer, but meeting Nikolai Foregger's resistance.
description: Sergei Eisenstein and Sergei Iutkevich rework the set design of 'The Veil of Columbina' another time, now under the title 'The Columbian Girl’s Garter'. Thescenario, which takes two months to develop, not only contains detailed stage directions, but also describes the movements of the actors, the lighting and the tricks in great detail. The production of the piece fails due to Nikolai Foregger's resistance.

title: Meets Lev Kuleshov and attends his Film Workshop for three months.
description: Sergei Eisenstein meets Lev Kuleshov for the first time in the Proletkult Theatre, who reports on the encounter in his memoirs: "I asked Sergei Eisenstein if I could work on sports training (gymnastics, expressive movement, boxing) with the students of our working group in the Proletkult House. Sergei Eisenstein agreed, but asked me in return to give lectures on film for the Proletkult group that he led [...] My lectures at the Proletkult began to interest Sergei Eisenstein and soon he came over to the Zone-Theatre in the evening [...] to our group and worked on montage exercises (only on paper as a script, of course). This went on every evening for three months and always with full zeal [...] We spent hours every night with montage exercises - without film material - of mass scenes. This is where certain common features and similarities between the mass scenes in 'Strike' and the same scenes in 'The Death Ray' come from. When Sergei Eisenstein studied with us, he proved with brilliance one of his sayings: 'Everyone can become a film director, but one must study for two years and the other for 200 years.' Sergei Eisenstein studied in the workshop for three months."
display temporal: Between the end of 1922 and January 1923
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 40

title: Sergei Eisenstein's first film work with the shooting for 'Glumov's Diary'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein's first film work with the shooting for 'Glumov's Diary'. Dziga Vertov is assigned to Eisenstein by Goskino as a consultant, but he leaves the recording work after two or three shots. Sergei Eisenstein is later amused that Vertov did not get along with "theatre people in white atlas and clown clapping".

title: First public performances of 'Enough Simplicity in Every Wise Man'.
description: First public performances of 'Enough Simplicity in Every Wise Man' in the First Workers' Theatre of Proletkult, Moscow, Nozdvizhenka 16. Scholars and contemporaries disagree on the exact premiere date. This expansion of eccentric attractions is met with an almost entirely positive response from the public and critics. In the discussion about the production, however, the question arises as to what this still has to do with Workers' Theatre.

title: Work on 'Precipice' is resumed. It is now to be staged under the title 'Patatras'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein and Valerian Pletnev work again on Pletnev's piece 'Precipice'. Grigoryi Aleksandrov joins as co-author. Eisenstein suggests to rewrite it, including some motifs from Upton Sinclair's novel 'King Coal' (1917). The new version is to be staged as a detective play under the title 'Patatras'. He sketches set and costume designs.

title: Publication of 'The Montage of Attractions' marks beginning of his theoretical-analytical work.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes the fundamental essay 'The Montage of Attractions'. With this staging principle of the dynamic and eccentric agitation theatre ("left wing" of Proletkult), which he developed together with Boris Arvatov, Sergei Eisenstein at the same time sets himself apart from the direction represented by Valerian Pletnev of the representational-narrative theatre ("right wing" of Proletkult). With this in the magazine of the LEF-Group published Manifesto, Sergei Eisenstein begins his theoretical-analytical work, parallel to his creative and practical theatre and film work.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 43

title: Premiere of 'Can You Hear Me, Moscow?'.
description: First performance of 'Can You Hear Me, Moscow?' in the First Workers' Theatre of the Proletkult. Due to the concrete task of the production, to intensify the mobilization of volunteers to Germany, Sergei Eisenstein turns for a short time to a sujet-related topic. The production, which uses sparse Grand Guignol resources, provokes strong emotional reactions in the audience.

title: Begins work on the design and direction of Sergei Tretiakov's melodrama 'Gas Masks'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein begins work on the design and direction of Sergei Tretiakov's melodrama 'Gas Masks', a collective drama whose treatment is "in the style of tangible, milieu-related everyday life". The goal of the production "is an agitation that organizes production and milieu". In this production, Sergei Eisenstein deals for the first time with the design of mass scenes, an elementary theme of his first films.

title: Renewed conflict with Proletkult triggered by the dispute over the copyright of the 'Strike' scenario.
description: Renewed conflict with Proletkult triggered by the dispute over the copyright of the 'Strike' scenario. In the following debate with Valerian Pletnev, the head of the executive office of the Moscow Proletkult, Sergei Eisenstein accuses Proletkult "that the executive organs [...] did not steer a fixed course of theatre, neither in the repertoire nor in questions of principle and form [...] On the part of Proletkult, the occupation with theatre work was a pure censorship issue. Proletkult's overall assessment of the work usually resulted in the sacramental formula "ideologically consistent", whereby 90% of this was related to the subject and the milieu-related coherence of the details. (B12.1, p. 204f.) Pletnev, on the other hand, takes a public stand against Eisenstein's "formalism and trickery" and "against the introduction of a number of dubious elements of Freudian provenance".

title: Sergei Eisenstein decides to leave Proletkult.
description: Sergei Eisenstein decides to leave Proletkult in the middle of november. "The reason for this lies [...] in the legal deviation of Proletkult's petty-bourgeois-realist attitude, which is absolutely incompatible with my work."

title: Starts working on a film based on 'Red Cavalry'.
description: Together with Yakov Bliokh and Grigori Aleksandrov, Sergei Eisenstein is working on systematizing the historical material and setting up the scenario for a film by the Sevzapkino Studio, "dedicated to the history of the 'Red Cavalry' [after Isaak Babel]". "Formally, the film will be a continuation of the ideas I already demonstrated in 'Strike', that is, it will present social-mass-related themes."

title: The Central Executive Committee of the USSR (CIK) decides to film the scenario presented by Nina Agadzhanova-Shutko for an anniversary film about the 1905 revolution.
description: The Central Executive Committee of the USSR (CIK), headed by Anatoli Lunacharski and with the co-chairmen Kasimir Malevich, Vsevolod Meyerhold, L. Mikhailov, Valerian Pletnev, V. Krasin, Kirill Shutko and Sergei Eisenstein decides to film the scenario presented by Nina Agadzhanova-Shutko for an anniversary film about the 1905 revolution. The plan is to create a panorama of the most important events of 1905, from the aftermath of the Russo-Japanese War to the proclamation of the 'Manifesto of October 17'. Sergei Eisenstein is commissioned to direct the film with the condition that one of the planned episodes be completed by December 20. The later 'Battleship Potemkin' runs under the working title 'The Year 1905'. The film project 'Red Cavalry' is postponed.

title: Estimates the time needed for 'The Year 1905' to be a total of 250 recording days with 18-20.000 people.
description: Sergei Eisenstein estimates the time needed for 'The year 1905' to be a total of 250 recording days with 18-20.000 people. He cites August 1926 as the completion date for the entire panorama film: "The film will portray the heroic pathos of the first Russian revolution and the forces that supported and determined it (the workers, peasants, soldiers, sailors, the student body, and the splitoff 'democracy' - the liberalists).

title: In Odessa the decision to focus on the events on the 'Battleshipt Potemkin' is taken.
description: Sergei Eisenstein's arrival in Odessa - At the advice of the director of Goskino, Mikhail Kapchinski, shooting is moved from Leningrad to Odessa on the Black Sea due to bad weather conditions. Thus the decision for the episode about the uprising of the Black Sea Fleet is made. The film project about 'The Year 1905' focuses on the events on the 'Battleship Potemkin': The sailors' revolt becomes an exemplary event of the revolution. Only 44 of the 820 shots of Nina Agadzhanova-Shutko's scenario are taken.

title: Sergei Eisenstein, Maksim Shtraukh and Aleksandr Levshin return to Moscow for studio recordings and the montage of the 'Battleship Potemkin'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein, Maksim Shtraukh and Aleksandr Levshin return to Moscow for studio recordings and the montage of 'Battleship Potemkin'; on the same day Sergei Eisenstein goes through 4500 meters of footage by himself. Eisenstein expands the principle of 'Montage of Attractions' by "dissecting elements of the bourgeois art he rejects - i.e. all elements aimed at illusion and consumption of art - and then assembling them in a 'objective manner' and with a new purpose". With these means of influence of the "bourgeoisie, which is forced into subbotnic work," he accommodates the viewing habits of the Soviet public and thus uses passivating elements of bourgeois art for agitation-"another tactical maneuver in the attack on the spectator, which is ridden under the slogan of Red October.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 61

description: Public premiere of the 'Battleship Potemkin' at the Art Cinema on Moscow's Arbat Square. The film is released by the First Goskino Studio. At the premiere the crew, all actors, the cinema orchestra and ushers appear in the uniform of the 'Potemkin' sailors.

title: Visits Berlin film studios and meets with personalities of the german film industry.
description: In Tempelhof Sergei Eisenstein makes the acquaintance of Emil Jannings during the shooting of Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau's 'Faust'; probably there's also an encounter with Murnau himself. While visiting the studios in Staaken he watches among others Luciano Albertini, Harry Liedtke and Manfred Noa during shooting. During the production of 'Metropolis' he discusses the advantages and disadvantages of the unchained camera technique ("Entfesselte Kamera") with Fritz Lang, Günther Rittau and Karl Freund. Thea von Harbou later presents to him the script development of 'Metropolis'.
people: Emil Jannings;Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau;Luciano Albertini;Harry Liedtke;Manfred Noa;Fritz Lang;Günther Rittau;Karl Freund;Thea von Harbou

title: Discusses the musical score for 'Battleship Potemkin' with Edmund Meisel.
description: Sergei Eisenstein and Edmund Meisel discuss the music for 'Potemkin', which Maria F. Andreeva, Maksim Gorki's wife, had commissioned. "I formulated my demands to Meisel for a music as rhythm, rhythm and above all pure rhythm. But not in the sense of rhythmic identities of sound and representation. This was a demand for a musical rhythm as a field of expression. This was most completely realized by Meisel in the fifth part."

title: A closed special screening of 'Battleship Potempkin' is arranged at the Ministry of the Reichswehr in reaction to its planned german release.
description: Alarmed by the intention of the Berlin film distributor 'Prometheus' to release 'Battleship Potemkin' in german cinemas, a closed special screening of the film is arranged at the Ministry of the Reichswehr in the presence of Admiral Hans Zenker, Head of the Naval Command, and Colonel General Hans von Seeckt, Head of the Army Command.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 65
reference: Esther added ranks of the personal in the Reichswehr for better understanding

title: First censorship hearing on the 'Battleship Potemkin' before the 2nd chamber of the Film Review Office Berlin.
description: First censorship hearing on 'Battleship Potemkin' before the 2nd chamber of the Film Review Office Berlin. The film is banned because it is "suitable for permanently endangering public order and security".
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 65

title: Meets Alfred Kerr.
description: Sergei Eisenstein meets Alfred Kerr, on whose intercession Eisenstein attributes the later licensing of 'Battleship Potemkin' by the Film Review Office.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 66

title: Battleship Potemkin' is licensed by the Film Review Office against the protest of the german military.
description: Revision hearing in front of the Supervisory Headquarters of the Film Review Office Berlin in the presence of Alfred Kerr and Erwin Piscator as experts. The film is licensed with cuts in 14 instances - that was 30.15 meters of film. 'Battleship Potemkin' is forbidden for young people. The Head of the Army Command, Colonel General Hans von Seeckt, asks interior minister Dr. Wilhelm Külz, "to prevent the performance by all possible means [...]", since the licensing of "this agitational and disintegrative film would mean an extraordinarily heavy and unnecessary burden on military discipline such as public peace and order".
keyword: Main Filmtestcentre Berlin;General Oberst Seekt;Dr. Külz;Battleship Potemkin
people: Alfred Kerr;Erwin Piscator;Hans von Seeckt;Wilhelm Külz
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 65-67

title: The Army Command prohibits the soldiers of the Reichswehr from visiting the cinemas showing 'Battleship Potemkin'.
description: The Army Command prohibits the soldiers of the Reichswehr from visiting the cinemas showing 'Battleship Potemkin'.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 67

title: German and prussian officials authorize the German premiere of 'Battleship Potemkin' in the Apollo Theatre.
description: Prussian Prime Minister Otto Braun, Berlin Police Commissioner Albert Grzesinski, prussian Minister of Culture Carl Becker, Chief Reich Prosecutor Ludwig Ebermeyer and "some gentlemen from the Reich Chancellery with their entourage" visit the Apollo Theatre in the afternoon and authorize the German premiere of 'Battleship Potemkin' in the evening.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 67

title: While the german left-wing is enthusiastic about 'Battleship Potemkin', right-wing and military groups try to get it cancelled even with violent measures.
description: The reactions to the german release of 'Battleship Potemkin' are polarized between positive and enthusiastic responses in left-wing outlets and the right-wing press being appalled and disgusted. In order to give the police a reason to prohibit the screenings because they endanger public peace, right-wing provocateurs disrupt the screenings for the first time on May 5th. In addition, a 'German Sailors' Club' threatens attacks with hand grenades if the film is not cancelled.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 69

title: German officials bring forward a motion to the Berlin Film Review Board  to revoce the license of 'Battleship Potemkin' for the entire territory of Germany.
description: Already shortly after the german premiere of 'Battleship Potemkin', foreign minister Gustav Stresemann and the Reich Cabinet had agreed that "all possible means must be taken to prevent further screenings of the film". Then on June 12, the interior minister of Württemberg, Eugen Bolz, brings forward a motion to the Berlin Film Review Office to revoce the license of 'Battleship Potemkin' for the entire territory of Germany.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 69

title: A "Committee to prevent the ban of Potemkin" with prominent supporters is formed in Berlin.
description: A 'Committee to prevent the ban of Potemkin' is formed in Berlin, whose protests are joined by Albert Einstein, Georg Bernhard, Ludwig von Gerlach, Veit Valentin, Captain Lothar Persius, Stefan Großmann, Leopold Jessner, Paul Lobe, Georg Kaiser, Alfred Kerr, Klabund, Max Liebermann, Erwin Piscator, Ernst Toller and Heinrich Zille, among others.
people: Albert Einstein;Georg Bernhard;Ludwig von Gerlach;Veit Valentin;Lothar Persius;Stefan Großmann;Leopold Jessner;Paul Lobe;Georg Kaiser;Alfred Kerr;Klabund;Max Liebermann;Erwin Piscator;Ernst Toller;Heinrich Zille
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. Marburg: Schüren Verlag;p. 85-88 f.
reference: Rundschreiben v. Piscator zum Ausschuss v. 26. Juni 1926 ist in der Max Liebermann Sammlung;AdK;erhalten: https://www.deutsche-digitale-bibliothek.de/item/BRSBO7BRIHPBBABW7GMESVEZLXWEYXNJ

title: Battleship Potemkin' is banned by the Film Review Office.
description: Against the protest of the prominent 'Committee to prevent the ban of Potemkin' and the left-wing civil press, 'Battleship Potemkin' is banned on 12 July.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 70

title: Battleship Potemkin' is licensed by the Film Review Office again, but in a controversial recut version.
description: Prometheus reworks the film and resubmits it to the Film Review Office at the end of July. In this very controversial version it is released again. A further hearing before the Film Review Office in October confirms this decision with the restriction that the visit is forbidden for adolescents. Despite temporary bans in Württemberg and Bavaria, 'Battleship Potemkin' has thus prevailed in the censorship.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 70; dates according to censorship documents in: 'Panzerkreuzer Potemkin'. title: Lectures about his stay in Germany in the ARRK.

title: Starts working on 'The General Line', a film about the socialist transformation of the village.
description: Near Moscow, Sergei Eisenstein is working on a film about the socialist transformation of the village according to the decisions of the XIV Party Congress. According to the initial conception, the film is supposed to "tie the bond between town and village more closely - one of the future tasks of the Bolshevism". Before the first recordings for the film project 'The General Line' Sergei Eisenstein studies archives of the Commissariat of Agriculture, complaints from farmers and attends meetings of the Peasant Council according to the method suggested by Nina Agadzhanova-Shutko. In July there are only eight days of shooting due to poor shooting conditions.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 70

title: In 'Berliner Tageblatt' an autobiographical article by Sergei Eisenstein written especially for the German readership is published.
description: Berliner Tageblatt', whose feature editor is Alfred Kerr, publishes the article 'Sergej Eisenstein über Sergej Eisenstein, den 'Potemkin'-Regisseur' ['S. Eisenstein about S. Eisenstein'], which Sergei Eisenstein has written especially for the German readership: "As for my view on cinema in general, I must confess that I understand it as bias and only bias. In my opinion, without a clear presentation of the "why" one cannot begin work on a film."
category: Biography and Personality;Writing and Teaching;Cinema and Theatre
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 71; English quote in: Eisenstein;Sergei (1982): 'Film essays and a lecture'. Ed. Jay Leyda;Princeton: Princeton University Press;pp. 14 f.

title: Writes the article 'Bela forgets the scissors'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes the article 'Bela forgets the scissors', a replica of Béla Balász's lecture 'Filmtradition und Filmzukunft' [On the Future of the Film'] held at the German Cinematographers' Club. Against Balász's view of the "figurative quality of the shot as the decisive factor", Sergei Eisenstein emphasizes: "The shot merely interprets the object in a setting to use it in juxtaposition to other sequences."
keyword: Bela forgets the scissors;Béla Balász;Film tradition and film future
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 71; Eisenstein;Sergei (1926): On the position of Béla Balázs. title: The film section of TEO accepts the literary script of the 'The General Line'.
description: The film section of TEO accepts the literary script of 'The General Line'. Its concept of showing the epic pathos of country life after the revolutionary pathos of 'Potemkin' fails, however, "because of the grids of the paragraph demands of former dramaturgical departments and the former main committee for film repertoire [...] And the good intentions to shape the pathos of socialism, which had descended blessingly on the flat land, withered away on the stalk - to use an agriculturalpoetic expression!"

title: On the occasion of its tenth anniversary Sergei Eisenstein is commissioned to shoot a film on the events of the 1917 October Revolution.
description: The Film Committee formed to organize the tenth anniversary of the October Revolution of 1917 commissions Sergei Eisenstein to shoot a feature film on the events of the revolution, consulting John Reed's book 'Ten Days That Shook the World' (1919). Under the title of this novel Eisenstein starts the preparations for the film later called 'October'; he studies materials that were compiled chronologically by the historian Aleksei V. Efimov.

title: Writes a first complete literary script for 'October' with Grigori Aleksandrov.
description: Sergei Eisenstein and Grigori Aleksandrov write a first complete literary script for 'October' in two parts and nine acts. In the first four acts the February Revolution, preparation for the October Revolution, storming of the Winter Palace and the Soviet Congress are to be shown. The fifth act contains the events of the October days. Acts 1-5 should form the first part of the film. For part two act six to eight provide a description of the civil war in the south, and the ninth act is dedicated to the first years of peaceful reconstruction.
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 74;additional information by Naum Kleiman

title: Writes the director's script for 'October' and plans the means by which the film should achieve its expressiveness.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes the director's script for 'October'. According to its conception, the film is supposed to point beyond the current occasion by the fact that in every detail of the overall composition the heroic atmosphere of the October Revolution spreads to the audience of all days. Accordingly, the selection of details of the means of action is carried out according to the aspect of greatest expressiveness, but also historical accuracy. The typage search transforms the city into a 'working department', museums are searched for epaulettes, sashes, spurs and representations of deities "which - starting with Christ and ending with African symbols - were supposed to symbolize the idea of the Kornilov coup 'for God, faith and fatherland' ... " In broad daylight, a bridge that is normally only raised at night is raised for filming, mass scenes take place with the participation of up to 5,000 people, in short: "From this time on, everything unusual and everything out of the ordinary was pushed onto the recording team of the 'October'.
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 77

works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 77

title: Begin of the shooting of the Storming of the Winter Palace.
description: Start of shooting for the Storming of the Winter Palace. According to a report by Eduard Tisse, a luminosity of 20000 amperes is used for the first time with 90 devices. Hewrites about the course of the shooting: » All major storming scenes were carried out within 10 days. Due to a lack of electricity, many scenes had to be combined during the shooting, especially during nightly mass scenes. We usually shot outside at night and indoors during the day: in the Smol'nyj, in the Volkshaus and in the pavilion of the Sovkino studio. For the largest nocturnal mass scenes, we installed the lighting two to three hours before the start of shooting, so that we could then set up the equipment in other places according to a precise plan. Once the shooting was finished at one location, we immediately rushed to a second, third, etc. In this way we were sometimes 36-42, even 52 hours without sleep. But in spite of this tense state we did not allow ourselves any botch-ups. All the mass scenes and all the other central shots were filmed from different points of view with two/three cameras, on which the cameramen Popov and Nil'son worked. Under the supervision of General Popov, all the recorded material was periodically brought to the laboratory in Moscow. For the first time, due to an absolute lack of time, we did not manage to look at the filmed material ourselves before the Leningrad filming was finished. Since we continued filming without interruption after our arrival in Moscow, I did not see the material until the last minute."
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 77

title: Arguments about the high cost of shooting and bureaucratic hurdles.
description: A diary entry documents beginning arguments between the film team and the production management about the high costs. Sergei Eisenstein finds an ally in the fight against bureaucratic obstruction in Nikolai Podvoiski, the leading consultant on 'October'. Eisenstein repeatedly and angrily points out "the worst enemy of any Soviet film - the Soviet film organization apparatus, on the red tape and the bureaucracy to which the brooms of the party conference [in March 1928]"."
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 78

title: The montage of 'October' according to the principle of 'intellectual film' begins.
description: Sergei Eisenstein begins with the montage of 49,000 meters of recorded material for 'October' and works on the montage principle of 'intellectual film': two sequence parts (pictograms) that exist independently of each other in their meanings are assigned to each other contrapuntally; from the dynamic collision of the pictograms, a "decision about what is being portrayed (read: the conclusion from what is portrayed)", an intellectual concept, emerges in the viewer. A film structured in a complex way according to this principle can finally give rise to a whole system of concepts through the contrapuntal use of emotional, documentary, graphic, colour, in short artistic means of influence. In 'October' Sergei Eisenstein tries to realize this principle in two sequences ('Kerenski's staircase ascent' and 'Gods sequence').On the door of the montage room hangs the note: "Here we are working on 'October'. Think about it before you enter."
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 80

title: Additional recordings are made in Moscow.

title: Drafts a plan for a division of the 'October'.
description: In order to edit the abundance of the filmed material, Sergei Eisenstein drafts a plan for a division of the 'October': Part 1 should contain the events from the February to the October revolution, part 2 the October revolution.
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 80

title: First notes of the plans to develop a film based on Karl Marx's 'The Capital'.
description: A note during the montage of 'October': "The decision has been made to film 'The Capital' according to the scenario of Karl Marx - this is the only possible formal way out." (Bl2.3, p. 289) Based on the 'Intellectual Montage' Sergei Eisenstein plans to make 'The Capital' a film about the method of dialectics. He begins with the collection of "Intellectual Attractions ", designs a 'subject backbone' as a starting point for the formation of chains of associations, which in 'film essays' should dialectically represent fundamental chapters of “The Capital”. As a model for the formal structure he thinks of James Joyce's 'Ulysses', the idea of a collection of 'film essays' arises when reading Henri Barbusse, 'Faits divers'.
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World;The Capital
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 80

title: First encounter with the American writer Theodore Dreiser.
description: First encounter with the American writer Theodore Dreiser, a "living Himalayan", in Moscow not before November. After discussions about his method of staging, Sergei Eisenstein shows Dreiser parts of 'The General Line' and 'October'. At least until 1938, they are connected - in addition to Sergei Eisenstein's visits during his stay in America and the plan for a film adaptation of Dreiser's novel 'An American Tragedy' - by an irregular exchange of letters, in which Dreiser offers Eisenstein his book 'The Financier' for film adaptation.
keyword: Theodore Dreiser;living Himalayan;October;General Line;An American Tragedy;The Financier
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World;The General Line;An American Tragedy
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 81

title: First meeting with the film critic Léon Moussinac in Moscow.
description: First meeting with the film critic Léon Moussinac in Moscow; Moussinac reports: "I could see what extraordinary inventiveness and joy of discovery he was gifted with and that a deep passion for innovation and creation occupied him. We spent many hours in animated conversation, indeed we talked day and night. His expressiveness and the accuracy of his thinking, but also the illuminating insight he attributed to certain words, gave his ideas a clear, understandable form. There could be no doubt that he would make his mark on the world as a rich man in the spirit of Karl Marx: As a man for whom his own fulfilment had become an inner necessity, a need [...] He was particularly curious and interested in questions of Futurism, Constructivism and Surrealism. Jacques Feyder's 'Visages d'enfants' was shown at a party given for me, and I was surprised how cleverly Sergei Eisenstein analysed the merits and demerits of the film, even though few French films came to Moscow at the time - a state of affairs, incidentally, that Russian filmmakers could not complain about enough."
keyword: Leon Moussinac;Karl Marx;Futurism;Constructivism and Surrealism;Jacques Feyder;Visages d'enfants
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 82

title: Meets and argues with the main representatives of the Novyi LEF in the house of Sergei Tretiakov.
description: Sergei Eisenstein meets with the main representatives of the Novyi LEF in the house of Sergei Tretiakov. Probably Sergei Tretiakov, Vladimir Maiakovski, Viktor Shklovsky, Aleksandr Rodchenko, Varvara Stepanova, Semion Kirsanov, Anton Lavinski and Esfir Shub were present. Even before the premiere of 'October', Eisenstein is heavily attacked by this group, as he does not present the October events as a documentary sequence of factographic material, but as an 'artistic game'. Sergei Eisenstein has nothing in common with the dogmatic demand of the Novyi LEF for documentary, unposed reproduction of real material, the schematic separation of feature and documentary film. A little later he explains with a clear allusion to 'Novyi Lef': "The theoretical novelty - the 'documentary film' - replaced the subject with the fact. Illusion against material. The replacement of aesthetic fetishisation was followed by a fetishism of material. But fetishism of the material is not yet materialism. It remains above all fetishism [...] The newly turned page must now be approached with the radically opposite motto: Scepticism of the material." With this, the separation from the LEF group is completed.
people: Sergei Tretiakov;Vladimir Maiakovski;Viktor Shklovsky;Aleksandr Rodchenko;Varvara Stepanova;Semion Kirsanov;Anton Lavinski;Esfir Shub
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 83

title: Sergei Eisenstein and others demand more involvement in the development of a soviet cinematography at the First All-Unions Party Conference on Film Questions in Moscow.
description: First All-Unions Party Conference on Film Questions in Moscow. In a proclamation read out on 18 March, Sergei Eisenstein, Grigori Aleksandrov, Abram Room, Grigori Kozintsev, Leonid Trauberg and others call for "a tight organisational management of the Russian film industry to maintain a uniform ideological line [...] The utilisation of the existing film specialists [...] has been extremely inefficient to this day. It was a serious organizational error not to have consulted the specialists to a greater extent before solving the general questions and tasks of the emerging Soviet cinematography, for the simple reason that the path and face of revolutionary cinematography [...] had been created through the long and arduous work of these very specialists."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 84

title: Becomes a teacher at GTK, where he teaches directing - with short interruptions - until his death.
description: Sergei Eisenstein becomes a teacher at GTK, where he teaches directing - with short interruptions - until his death. At the beginning of his teaching career, he demands the expansion of the subject "Dialectical Materialism", but does not succeed in doing so. Thereupon he begins his lectures "with compilatively collected facts about dialectics [...], because without that I could not state a single theoretically thought-out and well-founded sentence of my own field to them [the students]".
places: Soviet Union;Russia;Moscow;VGIK (All-Russian State Institute of Cinematography)
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 86 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein begins reworking the screenplay of 'The General Line' and new shooting days in the Caucasus.
description: Sergei Eisenstein begins reworking the screenplay of 'The General Line' and new shooting days in the Caucasus. For the first time Eisenstein uses the means of individualization (through Marfa Lapkina in the leading role) within the framework of a collectivist theme. In the selection of amateur actors he sticks to the principle of typography.All that remains of the first conception are the first three acts and the agitpropfilm of the second part. Other difficulties had to be overcome as well: Five participants in the film had died, and "our heroine: Marfa Lapkina faced motherhood. But with unaffected heroism and at a dizzying pace, Marfa was able to finish up in those important parts of the film that are inseparably linked to the sun and summertime."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 87

title: Sergei Eisenstein, Aleksandrov and Pudovkin write the 'manifesto on sound film'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein, Grigori Aleksandrov and Vsevolod Pudovkin write the 'manifesto on sound film'; they call for the use of sound as counterpoint and its sharp separation from visual forms; only in this way could a new, orchestral counterpoint of visual and acoustic forms be created.
works: The Future of Sound Films٫ a Statement
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 87

title: Joseph M. Schenk, president of United Artists, is in Moscow and is probably negotiating an engagement to Hollywood with Sergei Eisenstein.
description: Joseph M. Schenk, president of United Artists, is in Moscow and is probably negotiating an engagement to Hollywood with Sergei Eisenstein. In an open letter to People's Commissar for Education Anatoli Lunacharski, Eisenstein denies the rumors of an engagement to Hollywood that arise after Schenk's return: "My talent only allows me to film in the rich and fertile Russian fields. Abroad, I would be too far removed from the sources of my inspiration and perhaps fall into the mould of the thousand other international directors."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 88

title: Sees the Kabuki theatre in Moscow.
description: In Moscow Sergei Eisenstein sees the Kabuki Theatre, whose principle of representation is similar to Montage. He begins the essay 'An Unexpected Juncture' on the means of expression through the Audiovisual Counterpoint in Theatre and Cinema.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 88 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein begins with the montage of 'The General Line', developing and using the principle of Overtone Montage.
description: Sergei Eisenstein begins with the montage of 'The General Line'. At the same time, still under the impression of the Kabuki Theatre, he works on the theoretical questions of Overtone Montage. He develops its principle under the impression of the 'monistic ensemble' of Kabuki, in which every element (sound – movement – space – voice) is treated in a way that is identical in meaning: Various stimulus sources are combined in one picture; their composition lines are then not, as is usually the case, subordinated to a dominant in the course of the sequence, but are developed simultaneously in polyphonic montage. Just as in music there are so-called overtones and undertones in addition to the dominant keynote, so does "this optical play with the film material being recorded together with all its secondary tones [...] result in a visual overtone complex when in perfect harmony with the music". According to the principle of transitionl-fee playing, the abrupt change of emotional expression in the Kabuki, Eisenstein edits for example the 'separator' sequence: "By separating polar stages of facial expression [...] sharper precision is achieved in the <playing of doubt> around the separator. Does the milk condense or not? Fraud? Money? Here the psychological process of playing the motives - of faith and doubt - broken down into the two borders - of the joyful (certainty) and the dark (disappointment)."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 88 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein writes the programmatic essay 'Perspectives', in which he outlines the line of the future intellectual film.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes the programmatic essay 'Perspectives', in which he outlines the line of the future intellectual film: "The dualism of the spheres 'feeling' and 'reason' must be stopped by the new art. Science must be given back its sensuality, the intellectual process its flame and passion. The abstract thought process must be immersed in the liveliness of practical work. The castration of the speculative formula must be given back all the richness and opulence of a form that can be perceived as living."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 92

title: Sergei Eisenstein writes to Léon Moussinac about shooting the changed ending for 'The General Line' and his plans for a musical score and travelling the US.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes to Léon Moussinac about shooting the changed ending for 'The General Line' and his plans for a musical score and travelling the US: "Completely unexpectedly, I had to shoot something like a gripping near-epilogue [...] I have just made a remarkable journey through the North Caucasus and the Ukraine. I saw with my own eyes what is meant by 'building socialism'. There is nothing more moving or heroic! [...] My obsession is to set 'The Old and the New' to music. I have to do it abroad. I'm still not sure if everything will work out the way I want it to. That's why this must remain between us [...] After the European premiere I would like to go to the USA. Hollywood doesn't interest me in the USA at all, I want to see the country! And the sound film technology. Because I'm absolutely sure that the whole future of cinema lies in sound."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 92 f.

title: Together with Isaak Babel Sergei Eisenstein watches the military parade in Rostov-on-Don and makes the acquaintance of civil war hero Epifan Iovich Kovtiuch.
description: Sergei Eisenstein watches the military parade in Rostov-on-Don with Isaak Babel. Babel introduces him to the commanders of the cavalry army; Eisenstein makes the acquaintance of civil war hero Epifan Iovich Kovtiuch. Kovtiuch was a model for the protagonist Kozhuch in Aleksandr Serafimovich's novel 'The Iron Flood', from which Eisenstein had used several motifs for the script of the second, unrealised part of 'October'.
works: October: Ten Days That Shook the World
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 93; Additions by Naum Kleiman

title: Arrives in Berlin for the scoring and premiere of  'The General Line'.
description: Arrival in Berlin. Sergei Eisenstein wants to stay in Berlin for the scoring and the premiere of 'The General Line'. "Yes, 'The General Line" will be set to music. I take the standpoint that it can't be a dubbing; the sound, like the film, must be an independent part of the whole." In Berlin, Sergei Eisenstein lives in Martin Luther-Strasse, Pension Maria Louise. In the same pension lives L. Obolenski, actor, director (Kuleshov school) and sound engineer.

title: Sergei Eisenstein, Eduard Tisse and Grigori Aleksandrov travel to La Sarraz for the Congress of Independent Filmmakers.
description: Sergei Eisenstein, Eduard Tisse and Grigori Aleksandrov travel to La Sarraz for the Congress of Independent Filmmakers. They are held up for 24 hours at the Swiss border for political reasons before being admitted through the mediation of Hélène de Mandrot, the owner of the castle where the congress will take place. The aim of the congress is to coordinate the national independent film groups and to improve distribution; the long-term goal is to establish an international cooperative for the distribution and production of independent films based in Paris.

title: Sergei Eisenstein assists Eduard Tisse in shooting a film on abortion in Zurich.
description: In Zurich, producer Lazar Wechsler suggests an abortion film to Sergei Eisenstein. He refuses. In order to earn money, Eduard Tisse takes on this assignment. title: Lectures at the London Film Society.
description: Sergei Eisenstein gives the first of six lectures at the Film Society in London to selected audiences, including Ivor Montagu, Basil Wright, Paul Rotha and John Grierson. "In addition to the theoretical part, practical exercises are planned [...] The main topics are: l. Screenwriting technique; 2. montage and short cut; 3. conflict and solution; 4. the three forms of expression: a) Psychology in film; b) montage as a means of expression; c) allegory.". The remaining lectures take place on 21, 22, 25, 27 and 29 November.

title: Encounters James Joyce.
description: Encounter with James Joyce; Sergei Eisenstein listens to Joyce's spoken-word record with a part of 'Work in Progress' and is asked by the almost blind Joyce to show him his films. They discuss the possibility of a film version of 'Ulysses'. Joyce later tells his friend Jolas that only two directors were able to adapt 'Ulysses': Walter Ruttmann und Sergei Eisenstein.

title: Negotiations about film productions with 'Gaumont' and 'Societé Générale de Films' fail.
description: Negotiations with the production company 'Gaumont' fail; negotiations facilitated by Jean-George Auriol with the 'Societé Générale de Films' about the adaption of the novel 'Le Chemin de Buenos Aires' by Albert Londres, one of Sergei Eisenstein's favourite books, are equally unsuccessful, as Eisenstein categorically refuses the use of professional actors.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 102 f.

title: Grigori Aleksandrov shoots 'Romance Sentimentale' with participation of Sergei Eisenstein.
description: During Sergei Eisenstein's stay in London, Grigori Aleksandrov meets the pearl merchant Léonard Rosenthal in Paris, with whose girlfriend Mara Giry he shoots the short sound film 'Romance Sentimentale' (1930). Although Hans Richter explains that Eisenstein "never worried about the film and always emphasized to me that it wasn't him who was making the film, but Aleksandrov", one can assume from Eisenstein's statements about the state of sound film technology that he did participate. The mention of Eisenstein's name in the opening credits is due to a contractual stipulation according to which Eisenstein is to be named as director in any case - even if he does not direct the film.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 103

title: The General Line' is approved by the German censorship without changes.

title: German premiere of 'The General Line' under the title 'Der Kampf um die Erde'.
description: German premiere of 'The General Line' in Mozartsaal, Berlin, under the title 'Der Kampf um die Erde'. By changing the title, the German distribution company Prometheus tries to tie the film to the current political context of a land reform; they hoped for a provocative effect, which would revive the discussion about the land reform, and probably also speculated on effective advertisement after a ban.

title: Gives a lecture on the Intellectual Film at Sorbonne.
description: Sergei Eisenstein gives the lecture 'The Principles of the New Russian Cinema' on the Intellectual Film at the Sorbonne in front of 2000 people. As the police prevented the planned screening of the 'The General Line', the lecture expands into a discussion. Eisenstein talks about the difference between capitalist and communist film production and emphazises the role of the workers, whose critique is taken into account in the Soviet film production. Further he discusses the theory of Intellectual Film and again mentions his plan to film 'The Capital'.
