title: French artists and intellectuals support Sergei Eisenstein against the imminent expulsion from France.
description: Because of his talk at the Sorbonne University the Parisian Police threatens Sergei Eisenstein with expulsion from France. Eisenstein finds supporters in French artists and intellectuals. He talks to André Malraux, who persuades the professors at the Sorbonne to write a protest note against Eisenstein's imminent expulsion. Colette also assures him of her support; from the window of her apartment Eisenstein sees the garden of the Palais Royal, which he had designed as a decoration for 'The Storming of the Bastille' in 1920.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 107

title: Negotiation with Paramount Pictures Corporation.
description: Beginning of negotiations with Paramount's head of production, Jesse L. Lasky [and Adolph Zukor?] about an engagement to Hollywood. Sergei Eisenstein enforces that Grigori Aleksandrov and Eduard Tisse are included in the agreement. The projects proposed by Lasky include George Bernard Shaw's 'The Devil's Disciple' (1900), Herbert George Wells' 'War of the Worlds' (1899), Vicki Baum's 'Grand Hotel' (1929) and an adaption of 'The Trial of Zola' about Émile Zola and the Dreyfus-affair. Eisenstein is tempted to combine his experiences with reactionary France with Zola's novel characters: 'To make a transverse cut through the many-layered gateau of French reaction, splicing original characters from Zola’s novels on to my own vivid impressions, and to expose completely the gigantic class struggle that had raged around the trial of my favourite novelist. And to settle a few personal scores into the bargain ...' Further negotiations take place on 25 and 26 April.
people: Jesse Lasky; Adolph Zukor;Grigori Aleksandrov;Eduard Tisse;Émile Zola;George Bernard Shaw;Herbert George Wells;Vicky Baum
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 108; Eisenstein;Sergei (1995): 'Beyond the stars. The memoirs of Sergei Eisenstein' (Vol. 4);autobiographical writings edited by Richard Taylor. London: British Film Institute;p. 220

title: Visits Ivette Guilbert in Paris.
description: Sergei Eisenstein visits Ivette Guilbert, who advises him how to negotiate with Jesse Lasky: "Get as much money out of him as possible”! (From her tone I can hear: "Milk the pigeon!")" and entertains him throughout the afternoon with a performance of her acting skills.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 108

title: Sergei Eisenstein signs an agreement with Paramount.
description: Signs an agreement with Paramount in Paris. Sergei Eisenstein is assured complete freedom of choice of subject matter, direction and tendency. The contract, signed later in New York, stipulates that Eisenstein will alternately shoot a film for Paramount in six months and for Sovkino in Moscow in the following six months. Should he not have started with production within three months, the contract with Paramount would be terminated. For the preparatory work, Eisenstein receive $500 per week, plus $400 for his staff; $3,000 per week is budgeted for shooting. He makes the following statement to a Parisian journalist: "I am very happy to be able to make use of the great organization and all the technical improvements that are available to the film workers over there. Zukor is an energetic, very intelligent man, who is fully informed about the European production, and I was particularly surprised by his generous approach to film art".
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 109

title: With J.G. Bachmann as Associate Producer Sergei Eisenstein starts working first on 'The Glass House' and then 'Sutter's Gold'.
description: In Hollywood, J.G. Bachmann is assigned to Sergei Eisenstein as Associate Producer. Eisenstein plans to first shoot 'The Glass House'. He works with several scriptwriters, including Oliver H. P. Garrett, who had worked with Josef von Sternberg and Berthold Viertel; a viable script is not produced. Eisenstein has to abandon the plan he had been pursuing since 1927 and begins to work out his proposed project 'Sutter's Gold'.

title: Beginning of Major Frank Pease's anti-communist and anti-semitic campaign against Sergei Eisenstein.
description: Beginning of Major Frank Pease's anti-communist and anti-semitic campaign against Sergei Eisenstein with a telegram to Lasky saying, among other things: "If your Jewish priests and scholars do not have enough courage to tell you, and if you are not stopped from bringing a cutthroat red dog like Eisenstein into the country out of your own stupidity or lack of loyalty to this country which has given you more than you have ever had in the past, then be informed through me that we will do everything we can to have him thrown out again. We want no more red propaganda in this country. What are you trying to do, turn American cinema into a communist cesspool?"

title: Sergei Eisenstein answers to press reports, that he will not return to Hollywood after his first film for Paramount, but return to the Soviet Union.
description: In a Chicago newspaper Sergei Eisenstein answers to press reports, that he will not return to Hollywood after his first film for Paramount, but return to the Soviet Union: ""All this is a lie. After the premiere of my first film for Paramount, I am returning to the Soviet Union [...] My stay in America is intended to bring American cinematography closer to Soviet Russian cinematography [...] I came here with the agreement of the Soviet government and will return immediately after my vacation ends to work for the working people of the Soviet Union once again."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 114

title: The script for Sutter's Gold is rejected by Paramount.
description: The script for 'Sutter's Gold' is rejected by Paramount. Officially, the reason given is too high production costs; Ivor Montagu attributes the rejection to internal rivalries between Budd P. Schulberg and Jesse Lasky.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 115

title: Paramount proposes the adaption of 'An American Tragedy', although Sergei Eisenstein and his colleagues are sure that they wouldn't be allowed to produce it the way they intend.
description: Paramount proposes a long list of new project to Sergei Eisestein, including 'An American Tragedy' based on the novel by Theodore Dreiser. Dreiser's publisher, Horatio Liveright, is assigned to the group as a new assistant producer. Ivor Montagu reports on the reaction to Jesse Lasky's suggestion: "We discussed the situation until deep into the night. None of us had the slightest doubt. This was the death sentence for the Eisenstein expedition at Paramount. They would never let us do 'An American Tragedy'. They would never allow foreigners, some of them even Russians, to create 'An American Tragedy' the way we wanted to do it... So we decided unanimously and without pretending to be fools, not to back out at this point, but to accept the proposal and to do it our way, knowing, however, that it would not meet any expectations and would not be understood." Eisenstein is interested in Dreiser's novel above all "in the game of fate. In my treatment for Paramount I emphasized this line in every way. Clyde prepares the assassination of Roberta from long hand. But then the famous 'change of heart' occurs, and in the boat he thinks of something better. Soon afterwards, an accident really happens, in which Roberta dies. And the relentless cogwheels of the machine of iniquity, already started, further add to the chain of evidence all that Clyde had done in preparation for his murder."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 115

title: Gives the lecture 'The Dynamic Square' at a discussion of the 'Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences'.

title: The Labour Department asks Sergei Eisenstein to leave the country.

title: Sergei Eisenstein signs a contract regarding intellectual property rights for his Mexican film.
description: With the consent of Soiuzkino and the Russian-American joint stock company Amkino, Sergei Eisenstein signs an agreement with Mary Craig Sinclair: "Sergei Eisenstein agrees that all footage, negative films and positive copies, as well as any story or idea in said Mexican film produced by him or under his direction in Mexico will be the property of Mary Craig Sinclair, and that she may sell said material in any manner and at any price she desires. She shall be the sole owner of the world rights to said Mexican film and shall have the option to register the copyright to it in her name [...] The final scenes of the agreement are based on Sergei Eisenstein's desire to make a Mexican film according to his own ideas and in full confidence in Sergei Eisenstein's artistic integrity and in consideration of his promise that the film will not have a political theme, in appreciation of his prestige and talent.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 118 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein argues for spending the entire budget on filming in Mexico.
description: Sergei Eisenstein to Upton Sinclair: "We're working under very difficult conditions here. To make the not-yet-marketable material into a saleable film - we have to spend the whole $50,000. The rainy season is disrupting all our plans - the ranch, for example: we thought we could get everything done here in three weeks - and now we've been here six weeks and have only done three quarters of the work." Eisenstein explains why 38000 meters of exposed material is rather too little than too much for a 7 to 8 roll film. Upton Sinclair tells Hunter Kimborough that all the material was blocked by censorship, and that all positive prints were sent back to Mexico without their knowledge.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 126

title: Upton Sinclair expresses his understanding for the additional spending demanded by Sergei Eisenstein.
description: Upton Sinclair to Lev Monosson: "I can't blame Eisenstein for the extra spending. I want to let him finish the film in 1931 his own way and according to his own ideas, but - of course - if I can't do it, I can't do it".

title: Sergei Eisenstein's thoughts on the novel 'Maguey'.
description: Further negative material of the 'Maguey' novel is sent to California. Sergei Eisenstein to Upton Sinclair: "I think it is of a strong dramatic power and in the plastic effect is best achieved. The story takes place in pre-revolutionary Mexico, that is, before 1910 - the days of Porfirio Diaz's dictatorship (the portrayal of the general refers to Diaz). But I wouldn't invite anyone to a screening of these recordings – all  the  material is very tragic – death and executions – and because it hasn't been edited yet, it could have a depressive rather than cathartic effect on older ladies (which it will have in the final composition).
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 128

title: Demand of the Mexican government for a censored screeening of the finished Mexico film.
description: Upton Sinclair is sick. Hunter Kimborough sends him the text of a statement to the Mexican government, in which he describes their demand for a censored screening of the finished film as an obstacle to its financing.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 128

title: Upton Sinclair shares his concern about legths of shots filmed for '¡Que viva México!'.
description: Upton Sinclair suggests to Sergei Eisenstein that, for cost reasons out of the hacienda story, he assemble a five-reel film with a roll of  prologue and epilogue, then return to Mexico and make a second film from the new and unused old material. He is concerned about the length of the shots filmed so far. It is 45,720 meters.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 128

title: The film group prepares for the recordings of the Day of the Dead in Mexico City for '¡Que viva México!'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein's group prepares for the recordings of the Day of the Dead in Mexico City.  "I confess quite objectively and sincerely that the Day of the Dead, or, more correctly, what I had heard  about  it,  has  been  in  me  […]  that  passionate  longing which, despite my advanced age, can only be compared to the one which seizes every boy once and makes him dream of going to the land of the red - skinned Indians James Fenimore Coopers or to Marseilles, in order to visit with his own eyes the prison cell in the castle If, from which the later Count of Monte Cristo  had  once  fled!" Serious differences between Hunter Kimborough and Sergei Eisenstein. Kimborough protests unsuccessfully against further bullfighting and fiesta recordings.
keyword: Count of Monte Cristo;Hunter S. Kimborough;¡Que viva México!
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 129

title: Upton Sinclair is sick.
description: Upton Sinclair is sick.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 129

title: Serious differences between Hunter Kimborough and Sergei Eisenstein over the financing of '¡Que viva México!'.
description: Serious differences between Hunter Kimborough and Sergei Eisenstein. Kimborough to  Upton Sinclair: "Sergei Eisenstein boasts that if money is impossible to raise, he will approach his friends [...]. Plans 2-3 months of work here - waste our time shooting fiestas, bullfights – suggest you telegraph him [...] money is impossible to raise - prepare to return to Hollywood." Sinclair reiterates his concerns about the length of the film and the August 28 proposal. MGM is willing to do the dubbing for a story  film.  It  was  indeed  apparent  that  Sergei Eisenstein  was  editing  an excessively  long  version  and  that  it  would  be  rejected  by Hollywood. Sinclair goes on to say that if Sergei Eisenstein dropped an episode during editing, it would not be noticed. Sinclair  to  Lev Monosson: "Throughout  the  film, the hacienda episode alone forms a continuous story of interest to the audience."
keyword: Hunter S. Kimborough;Upton Sinclair;¡Que viva México!
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 129

title: Sergei Eisenstein rejects Upton Sinclair's proposal of 28 August to make the Hacienda episode into a separate film according to Hollywood standards.
description: In a letter to Upton Sinclair, Sergei Eisenstein rejects his August 28 proposal. This was the same as making the death of Polonius in Hamlet a spectacle of its own and the rest a new spectacle. Eisenstein fears that he will be called back to Russia immediately after completion of the first film. He reports contacts to Universal, from which he hopes for further financing.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 129 f.

title: Lev Monosson informs Upton Sinclair about the conditions under which Amkino will invest money in the Mexico Film.
description: Lev Monosson informs Upton Sinclair about the conditions under which Amkino will invest  $25,000 in the Mexico film. He also writes about Sinclair's August 28 proposal: "As far as I know, such a  procedure is only undertaken by unreliable and irresponsible so-called independent producers who don't give a damn about the director's name and artistic reputation [...] One of the conditions for Amkino's involvement is that the amount of work still to be done  on  the  film  is  identified  and  precisely  and  definitively determined, as well as the maximum amount of time for editing and dubbing in Hollywood." Sinclair sends Monosson a form of the articles of association of the 'Mexican Picture Trust'.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 130

title: Upton Sinclair sends Lev Monosson a statement of investments and expenditures for the Mexico film.
description: Upton Sinclair sends Lev Monosson a statement of investments and expenditures. According to this, 43,000 of the 50,000 dollars have been spent so far.  Sinclair repeats, in a toned-down form, Hunter Kimborough's accusations against Sergei Eisenstein and mentions that Eisenstein had not given a contractual guarantee for the montage. Asked to be allowed to use part of the money promised by Amkino for the stay in Mexico, otherwise he would have to call Sergei Eisenstein back shortly.

title: Upton Sinclair and Lev Monosson negotiate finances of '¡Que viva México!'. Sinclair complains that Eisenstein ignores his questions and worries.
description: Upton Sinclair and Lev Monosson exchange of letters with the agreement that $5,000 of the Amkino investment will be used for  filming,  the  rest  of  $20,000  for  dubbing  and  editing  in Hollywood.  Lev Monosson defends Sergei Eisenstein against Hunter Kimborough's accusations and advises Sinclair to go to Mexico himself. In his response, Sinclair points out his ill health and complains that Sergei Eisenstein ignores his questions and concerns.

title: Upton Sinclair demands a final production plan from Sergei Eisenstein for the remaining weeks in Mexico with the threat to stop the money transfers otherwise.
description: Grigori Aleksandrov recovered. Upton Sinclair tells Sergei Eisenstein about the contract with Amkino. He demands a final production plan with the threat to stop money transfers. Kimborough sends this production plan drawn up by Aleksandrov and Sergei Eisenstein, according to which about 120 days of shooting and about 35,000 dollars are still needed. Hunter Kimborough reports an improvement in his relationship with Sergei Eisenstein, but: "He is like a Negro. Nice words and consideration do not help."

title: Filming for the epilogue at the celebrations of the Day of the Dead in Mexico.
description: Filming for the epilogue at the celebrations of the Day of the Dead. "On  this  day [...]  everything  is  decorated  with the  symbols  of death, especially with skulls [...] And then the masks! Who would not put on the cardboard mask of death on this day? Who would not dance, the laughing face hidden behind the mask? [...] All of them - the good as well as the bad, the exploited as well as the exploiters, the bearers of life as well as the knights of death - they are all equal in this carnival hustle and bustle, they all hide behind the white, teeth breaking cardboard mask of the skull. But in the moment when the whirl reaches its climax, it suddenly breaks off: the masks are torn off, one  after the  other the  heads  of the  peons,  the  matadors,  the workers [...] exuberant life radiates from the coal black eyes... With a quick movement of the hand also [the masks of all those who in our film have played a negative role] are pulled down ...But these are not just the carnival masks made of cardboard, this is much more! Other masks fall with them, because under [their] cardboard masks are not the faces of living people, but ... real skulls.  [...]  These  are  corpses. The common  corpse  of  the socially doomed class."
keyword: Day of the Dead;¡Que viva México!
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 133 f.

Communication  with  him  was  only possible through Grigori Aleksandrov. Is outraged by a  resentation of scenes he has not yet seen and an article by Edmund Wilson in the New Republic. He agrees with Paramount as a negotiating partner, but MGM should only be contacted in an extreme emergency.

title: Sergei Eisenstien writes to Upton Sinclair that the Mexican consulate should not exercise  censorship. Joseph Stalin writes to Sinclair that Eisenstein has lost the trust of the people in the Soviet Union.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes Upton Sinclair that the Mexican consulate should not exercise censorship and blames Kimborough for the problem. Joseph Stalin's telegram to Sinclair: "Sergei Eisenstein has lost the trust of his comrades in the Soviet Union Stop He is considered a deserter who has broken with his country Stop Fear that our people may soon have no interest in him".

title: Upton Sinclair defends Sergei Eisenstein against Joseph Stalin's accusations.
description: Upton Sinclair to Joseph Stalin: Sergei Eisenstein could easily have had the opportunity  to  break  away  from  Moscow  during  his  stay  in America. Instead, he had always been loyal to the Soviet Union and had been attacked for that reason. His long stay in Mexico was not his fault; it was certain that Sergei Eisenstein would return to the USSR when the film was finished.

title: Sergei Eisenstein asks Upton Sinclair to call off Hunter Kimborough.
description: Sergei Eisenstein's telegram to Upton Sinclair: "Hunter completely crazy and obnoxious [...] Please call him off immediately - situation intolerable." On the same day, a telegram with similar contents, signed by Grigori Aleksandrov, Eduard Tisse and Eisenstein, follows.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 136

title: Upton Sinclair writes to Sergei Eisenstein that the difficulties withAmkino are due to Eisenstein's direct negotiations.
description: Upton Sinclair writes to Sergei Eisenstein that the difficulties with Amkino are due to Eisenstein's direct negotiations. He reports of new donors; it is therefore no longer necessary to show the uncut recordings. Amkino justifies the temporary suspension of the contract fulfillment with Eisenstein's low reputation in the USSR and his complete lack of reaction. Upton Sinclair grants Hunter Kimborough full power of attorney. Besides this, Kimborough is to be the first to read Sinclair's letters to Eisenstein. It is up to him to decide whether to forward them. Eisenstein suggests that all money should be sent to him, since Kimborough is unreliable. Promises to send an expense report every two weeks.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 136 f.

title: Hunter Kimborough leaves Mexico. Sergei Eisenstein mentions toUpton Sinclair the suspicion that Kimborough had embezzled money.
description: Hunter Kimborough leaves Mexico. Sergei Eisenstein mentions toUpton Sinclair the suspicion that Kimborough had embezzled money. Allows a visual demonstration of the uncut parts for Salka Viertel. In his letter to Amkino, he only stated that he would finish the film fastest with $10,000.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 137

title: Upton Sinclair comments in asharp tone the breach of contract of Amkino.
description: Upton Sinclair's letter to Amkino: he comments in a sharp tone on the breach of contract; the contract had been made with the Mexican Picture Trust, Eisenstein was only an employee of the Trust. He explains again that the long shooting time is due to poor working conditions. A carbon copy of the letter is sent toEisenstein. Eisenstein is filming the Fiesta in Guadelupe.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 137

title: Sergei Eisenstein agrees with Upton Sinclair's letter of 27 December.
description: Sergei Eisenstein agrees with Upton Sinclair's letter of 27 December. His suggestion, he says, was an act of desperation. "Day after day we receive the most panicky letters from one mother, sister, wife and secretary to another, and no official statement that anything is developing positively."

title: Sergei Eisenstein memorizes his accusations against Hunter Kimborough and does not see any possibility of distributing the Mexican ruling party's commissioned film in the United States.
description: Eisenstein again memorizes his accusations against Hunter Kimborough. Now that Kimborough is no longer there, the work is much better, he says, because his main activity was to obstruct their work. Does not see any possibility of distributing the Mexican ruling party's commissioned film in the United States; outside Mexico it would damage his reputation.

title: Sergei Eisenstein starts working on a comedy film 'Maksim Maksimovich Maksim', which will remain unfinished.
description: Sergei Eisenstein takes up the idea of a comedy and works on the unrealized project 'Maksim Maksimovich Maksim'. At the same time, he makes notes on the basic principle of comedy. Five years later, Sergei Eisenstein begins work on a comprehensive unfinished study of comedy.

title: Upton Sinclair writes Viktor Smirnov that the material from '¡Que viva México!' was edited into three films.
description: Upton Sinclair writes Viktor Smirnov that the material from '¡Que viva México!' has been edited into three films: the nine reel 'Hacienda episode' and the five reel 'Tehuantepec' and 'Bullfight episode'. Offers Amkino the complete negative for $75,000.

title: Sergei Eisenstein is informed that Upton Sinclair will not send '¡Que viva México!' to Moscow for editing.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is informed by a newspaper clipping sent to him by Seymour Stern that Upton Sinclair will not send the Mexico film to Moscow for editing. He locks himself in his apartment and carries himself with suicidal thoughts.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 144

title: Amkino makes an offer to Upton Sinclair to buy the negatives of '¡Que viva México!'.

source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 144

title: Vsevolod Vishnevski and Aleksandr Dovzhenko talk to Sergei Eisenstein about Dovzhenko's film project 'lvan', about Sergei Eisenstein's plans and his studies on Gogol.
description: Vsevolod Vishnevski and Aleksandr Dovzhenko talk to Sergei Eisenstein about Dovzhenko's film project 'lvan' (1932), about Sergei Eisenstein's plans and his studies on Gogol.

title: Sergei Eisenstein dictates the as yet unpublished essay 'Theory of Conflict'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein dictates the as yet unpublished essay 'Theory of Conflict'. First reference to the textbook 'Direction, Art of Mise-en-scène', which remains a fragment: "1931-1933: Final introduction of the system. The scientific work at GIK. (The publication is expected in 1933/34.)"
places: Soviet Union;Russia;Moscow;VGIK (All-Russian State Institute of Cinematography)

title: Sergei Eisenstein meets the writer and theorist of symbolism Andrei Bely and studies Nikolai V. Gogol.
description: Sergei Eisenstein meets the writer and theorist of symbolism Andrei Bely; During his study of Nikolai Gogol he reads the manuscript of the treatise 'Gogol's Mastery' (1934) by Belyj, an analysis of Gogol's pictorial and compositional structure.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 146

title: Sergei Eisenstein talks with Vsevolod Vishnevski.
description: Sergei Eisenstein talks with Vsevolod Vishnevski about film dramaturgy and his play 'Optimistic Tragedy'. Sergei Eisenstein tells Vishnevski that everything, from Aristotle to the present day, has to be turned upside down. The time of qualitative changes in film had dawned. Sergei Eisenstein regrets that Vishnevski has fallen out with Vsevolod Meyerhold. "Meyerhold is a master," he says, "one must be lenient with him."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 146

title: Sergei Eisenstein starts working on 'Granite of Film-Science'.

description: At the Moscow studio of Sovkino, Sergei Eisenstein signs a contract with Anatoli K. Vinogradov for the writing of a screenplay for Vinogradov's film novella 'The Black Consul', which focuses on the leader of the Haitian liberation movement, François Dominique Toussaint I'Ouverture, the 'Black Napoleon'.

description: Sergei Eisenstein begins lecture series on composition within the shot at the GIK. As exercise material he chooses the murder of Aljona Ivanova by Raskolnikov in Dostoevski's novel 'Crime and Punishment'.

description: Sergei Eisenstein formulates a thirty page statement on '¡Que viva México!' and addresses it to Joseph Freeman for publication in 'New Masses'. The statement remains unpublished because 'New Masses' supports Upton Sinclair's campaign for the governorship of California.

title: Joseph Goebbels calls for a "National Socialist Battleship Potemkin" in a speech to the filmmakers of Berlin at the Kroll Opera.

title: Sergei Eisenstein writes an open letter to the German Minister of Propaganda, Joseph Goebbels.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes an open letter to the German Minister of Propaganda, Jospeh Goebbels, in which he points out the fundamental difference between the Russian Revolution and the National Socialist seizure of power, which would never allow a 'Battleship Potemkin'.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 148

title: Sergei Eisenstein continues to work with Zarchi on the theatre play 'The Second Moscow'.

title: Deals with Lewis Carrol's fairy tale 'Alice in Wonderland'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein deals with Lewis Carrol's nonsense fairy tale 'Alice in Wonderland' and asks his friends in Western countries for secondary literature.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 149

title: Writes the essay 'E! On The Clarity of Film Language'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes the essay 'E! On The Clarity of Film Language'. Using the example of the welcoming scene of the 'Potemkin' by the people of Odessa, he once again examines the principle of montage as the "strongest means of composition for the artistic realization of a sujet." After the break of the Soviet silent film with sujet and individual hero there is now "the chance to rethink the basics and problems of the film sujet in a new way [...]".
keyword: On the Purity of the Language of Film;Battleship Potemkin
works: E! On The Clarity of Film Language;Battleship Potemkin
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 149

title: Sergei Eisenstein visits Maksim Gorki.
description: Sergei Eisenstein visits Maksim Gorki, who "in the closest circle of friends (...) entrusted us with the design of the scenario for a film about the children of the past, about the children of the civil war and the re-education of neglected youths". Gorki's request to film the scenario was rejected by Sergei Eisenstein.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 149 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein writes the article 'The Middle of Three'.
description: In Kislovodsk, Sergei Eisenstein writes 'The Middle of Three', an article about the second quinquennium (1924-1929) of Soviet cinema.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 150

title: Sergei Eisenstein works as a script consultant for the Ukrainian children's film studio and later teaches at GIK again with some prominent students in his class.
description: Sergei Eisenstein works as a script consultant for the Ukrainian children's film studio in Yalta and in the Odessa studio of VUFKU; he visits the youth film studio in Artek and makes a short detour to Alupka, where he had filmed the Three Lions for 'Battleship Potemkin' in 1925. After his return to Moscow he teaches at the GIK again. Among his students are Jay Leyda and Herbert P. J. Marshall.
places: Soviet Union;Russia;Yalta;Odessa;Artek;Alupka;Moscow;VUFKU (All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration);VGIK (All-Russian State Institute of Cinematography);Travels

title: Sergei Eisenstein meets Paul Robeson and his wife.
description: Paul Robeson and his wife come to Moscow at Sergei Eisenstein's invitation to talk about the filming of 'The Black Consul'. On the first evening they see a performance of Nikolai Gogol's 'Revisor' at the Meyerhold Theatre and then discuss the evolution of languages and music as a comparable expression of cultural development.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 150 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein gives a banquet in honor of Paul Robeson and gives a welcome speech.
description: In the House of Film Sergei Eisenstein gives a banquet in honor of Paul Robeson and gives a welcome speech.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 151

title: Sergei Eisenstein gives a New Year's Eve party in the House of the Film.
description: Sergei Eisenstein gives a New Year's Eve party in the House of the Film.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 151

title: Sergei Eisenstein opens as chairman of Conference of Soviet Film Workers on the occasion of the 15th anniversary of the USSR.
description: Sergei Eisenstein opens the All-Union Conference of Soviet Film Workers on the occasion of the 15th anniversary of the USSR as chairman. In his main lecture, he analyzes the history of the development of Soviet film from the experimental use of typography and montage to the current rediscovery of the sujet and the actor; he sees a development that points the way to classical Soviet film.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 151

title: Sergei Eisenstein is attacked by several participants of the Conference of Soviet Film Workers.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is sharply attacked by several participants of the Conference of Soviet Film Workers, among them Leonid Trauberg, Sergei Iutkevich, Sergei Vasilev and Vsevolod Pudovkin, because of his concentration on theoretical studies that keep him from film production. Aleksandr Dovzhenko explains in his speech among other things: (...) "When I listen to an Sergei Eisenstein lecture, I get scared that he knows so much and has such a bright head that he can't seem to finish a film. (...) Your film, Sergei Mikhailovich, is ten times more valuable to me than your theory. (...)".
people: Leonid Trauberg;Sergei Iutkevich;Sergei Vasilev;Vsevolod Pudovkin;Aleksandr Dovzhenko
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 151-153

title: At a ceremony at the Bolshoi Theatre, Sergei Eisenstein is awarded merely with the title of 'Deserved Artist'.
description: At a ceremony at the Bolshoi Theatre, Sergei Eisenstein, together with Eduard Tisse, Lev Kuleshov and Nathan Zarchi, is awarded merely with the title of 'Deserved Artist'. Before him Vsevolod Pudovkin, Aleksandr Dovzhenko and Friedrich Ermler are awarded the 'Order of Lenin'; Valerian Pletnev and Svedchikov receive the 'Order of the Red Banner', Dziga Vertov and Grigori Aleksandrov the 'Order of the Red Star'.
people: Eduard Tisse;Lev Kuleshov;Nathan Zarchi;Vsevolod Pudovkin;Aleksandr Dovzhenko;Friedrich Ermler;Valerian Pletnev;Dziga Vertov;Grigori Aleksandrov
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 153

title: In the closing speech at the Conference of Soviet Film Workers, Sergei Eisenstein defends his theoretical work for which he was earlier contradicted.
description: In the closing speech, Sergei Eisenstein defends his theoretical work once again. The four-tier award, "I interpret as follows: the point is that I have not been involved in any film production for several years; I take this decision as a call from the party and the government to resume film production”.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 153

title: First production preparations for 'Bezhin Meadow'. Sergei Eisenstein also creates a series of drawings for the mise-en-scène.
description: First production preparations for 'Bezhin Meadow'. With students at the GIK, Sergei Eisenstein creates a series of drawings for the mise-en-scène.

title: Meeting with the Chinese actor Mei Lanfang.
description: Meeting with the Chinese actor Mei Lanfang. Sergei Eisenstein, who had already directed the recordings for a short documentary film about Mei Lanfang's arrival in Moscow, suggests the production of a sound film about his acting. Mei Lanfang agrees. On March 29, Sergei Eisenstein and Lanfang and all the actors of the play 'Duel at Rainbow Pass' meet in the Mosfilm Studio. The shooting goes on until midnight.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 153-156

title: Sergei Eisenstein revises the script of 'Bezhin Meadow'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein revises the script of 'Bezhin Meadow' written by Aleksandr Rzheshevski, which is based on an actual event and is fleshed out with motifs from Ivan S. Turgenev's 'Record of a Hunter'.
keyword: Bežin Meadow;Aleksandr Rzheshevski;Ivan S. Turgenev;Record of a Hunter
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 156

title: Start of shooting of 'Bezhin Meadow' with the prologue in the orchards of Kolomenskoe.
description: Start of shooting of the 'Bezhin Meadow' with the prologue in the orchards of Kolomenskoe near Moscow. For the first time Sergei Eisenstein uses professional actors, according to Boris Zachava and Elizaveta Sergeevna. In addition, Eisenstein follows the principle of typage and the representation by laymen as much as possible. From Jay Leyda's production diary it becomes clear with what care Sergei Eisenstein works on the selection of the actors.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 156-157

title: Mass scenes for 'Bezhin Meadow' are first recorded without sound equipment.
description: At six o'clock in the morning Sergei Eisenstein and six members of his team fly to Armavir and Sovchoz 'Stalin', where the mass scenes are first recorded without sound equipment. Sergei Eisenstein explains to Jay Leyda: "On the editing table, this episode will be treated in the same way as the work of a composer composing a four-part fugue. The material we are filming here is only one of the voices. The third and fourth voices consist noise and speech."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 157

title: Arrival of the recording team in Charkov, where the pure play scenes of 'Bezhin Meadow' are recorded.
description: Arrival of the recording team in Charkov, where – now with sound – the pure play scenes are recorded. Sergei Eisenstein, suffering from food poisoning in Moscow, arrives later and still half sick. At his request, two kilometers of telephone poles and lines are removed, as he sees the composition of the picture disturbed by them.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 157-158

title: Return to Moscow from shooting 'Bezhin Meadow'.
description: Return to Moscow from the shooting of 'Bezhin Meadow'. On a cornfield near the Mosfilm studios, the team works on night shots. Jay Leyda: "Behind the camera there was a picture that was as strange as it was in front of it. The team - and the guests - stood in the background like in a circle: friends, acquaintances, studio staff from all the studios, other directors."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 158

title: Sergei Eisenstein furnishes his new four-room apartment.
description: Sergei Eisenstein furnishes his new four-room apartment. He asks Marie Seton for a Victorian wall mirror in which the whole room is reflected, and for a bouquet of Victorian wax flowers for his Datcha, which is under construction.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 158

title: Eisenstein falls ill with smallpox.
description: Sergei Eisenstein falls ill with smallpox and has to be in quarantine for three weeks; after that he stays at a health resort in Kislovodsk.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 158

title: Sergei Eisenstein resumes work on the 'Bezhin Meadow'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein resumes work on 'Bezhin Meadow'.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 158

title: Sergei Eisenstein falls ill with flu.
description: After six weeks of shooting Sergei Eisenstein falls ill with flu and has to interrupt work on 'Bezhin Meadow' for three weeks.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 158

title: Boris Shumiatski criticizes that the socialist-realist portrayal of the class struggle in 'Bezhin Meadow' was supplanted by a titanic struggle between good and evil.
description: After looking at the material recorded so far, Boris Shumiatski criticizes that the socialist-realist portrayal of the class struggle in the village during the period of collectivization was supplanted by a titanic struggle between good and evil. In Boris Shumiatski's view, the father plays the role of Abraham, who sacrifices his son. Sergei Eisenstein thereupon rewrites the screenplay with Isaak Babel.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 158 f.

title: The second version of the 'Granite of Film-Science' is published under the title: 'Programme for Teaching the Theory and Practice of Direction' in the magazine 'Iskusstvo Kino'.
description: In the magazine 'Iskusstvo Kino' the second version of 'Granite of Film-Science' is published under the title: 'Programme for Teaching the Theory and Practice of Direction', a detailed description of theoretical and practical exercises of the eight semesters of directing studies at the GIK. The student leaves the institute as a 'qualified co-director'; after an internship with at least one whole film and submission of a production report, he receives the title 'Qualified Director'.
works: Granite of Film-Science٫ Programme for Teaching the Theory and Practice of Direction
additional: VGIK (All-Russian State Institute of Cinematography);Iskusstvo Kino;Lecture

title: Mikhail Romm reportes about Sergei Eisenstein's lectures.
description: The director Mikhail Romm, who had heard Sergei Eisenstein's lectures at the GIK, reports about the lectures: "Even the most impeccable stenographic transcript could not convey the atmosphere of Sergei Mikhailovichs lectures. For each of his lectures was a great performance, a theatrical act of a special kind".

title: Vsevolod Meyerhold sends Sergei Eisenstein his portrait photo with a dedication.
description: Vsevolod Meyerhold sends Sergei Eisenstein his portrait photo. On the collar of his shirt he writes the dedication: "I am proud of the student who has already become a master. I love the master who has already created a school. To this student, this master - Sergei Eisenstein - my reverence"

title: Resumption of the shooting of 'Bezhin Meadow' in Yalta and Odessa according to the new script.
description: Resumption of the shooting of the 'Bezhin Meadow' in Yalta and Odessa according to the new script. In Odessa, already "with the foreboding of imminent inconveniences because of the Bezhin Meadow, Sergei Eisenstein discovers two paintings of the Italian painter Allessandro Magnasco, "because it is interesting that his monks - probably more than El Greco - determined the shape and movements of my 'Ivan IV' [Ivan the Terrible] [...] stylistically".
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 162

title: Sergei Eisenstein returns to Moscow.

title: Sergei Eisenstein shows Lion Feuchtwanger 'Bezhin Meadow' in rough cut.
description: Sergei Eisenstein shows Lion Feuchtwanger 'Bezhin Meadow' in rough cut. (running time: five hours). Lion Feuchtwanger: "He was worried about having to cut a lot out of the campfire scenes, scenes in which he had a special interest. He explained to me how happy he was that these scenes had succeeded in daylight. However, he feared that the film would not be understood.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 162

title: Paul Robeson promises to be available for the filming of 'The Black Consul'.
description: Paul Robeson promises Sergei Eisenstein during his stay in Moscow to be available to him from July to October next year for the filming of 'The Black Consul'.

title: Sergei Eisenstein sends a letter to Jay Leyda.
description: Sergei Eisenstein sends a letter to Jay Leyda: "I hope to finish shooting [of 'Bezhin Meadow'] in three to four weeks. Some have already seen the unedited footage and were very deeply impressed - everyone sees it as a return and reawakening of a qualitatively new film poetry".

title: All work on 'Bezhin Meadow' is immediatley stopped.
description: By order of the GUK, all work on 'Bezhin Meadow' is immediately and permanently stopped. In the reasoning for the decision, Boris Shumiatski blames Sergei Eisenstein for the waste of the provided funds - until now the production had cost two million rubles -, subjectivism, addiction to biblical and mythological typification, impoverishment of ideological content and formalistic retreat.
additional: GUK (Head Office of the Soviet Film Industry)
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 163

title: Letter from Vsevolod Vishnevski on the 'Bezhin Meadow' footage.
description: After a screening of the footage of 'Bezhin Meadow' the playwright Vsevolod Vishnevski writes an enthusiastic letter in which he emphasises Eisenstein's important role in the art scene and describes his impressions of 'Bezhin Meadow'. While watching the material, Vishnevski saw, breathed and felt beauty. For him, the film had qualities that had not existed in cinematic art for a very long time.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 163

title: Bezhin Meadow' is condemmed by film artists.
description: During a three-day conference, 'Bezhin Meadow' is officially condemned by film artists.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 163 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein publishes a self-critical article about the mistakes of the 'Bezhin Meadow'.
description: In April, Sergei Eisenstein publishes the self-critical article 'The Mistakes of Bezhin Meadow'. He explains among other things "My stylistic endeavours and my inclinations draw me strongly towards the general, the generalised, towards generalisation. But is that the generalisation, the 'general' that Marxist doctrine has taught us? No. Because in my work, generalisation absorbs the particular. Instead of being detected through what is concretely particular, the generalisation dissipates into fragmented abstraction. [...] I created the picture not out of the flesh and blood of socialist reality, but out of a tissue of associations and theoretical conceptions relating to that reality."
keyword: The Mistakes of the Bezhin Meadow
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 164; Eisenstein;Sergei (1922-1934): 'Writings - selected works'. Ed. by Taylor;Richard (1988). London/New York: I. B. Tauris;p. 101-104

title: Closed screening of the first and second version of 'Bezhin Meadow'.
description: Closed screening of the first and second version of 'Bezhin Meadow'. Vsevolod Vishnevski notes in his diary: "Eisenstein has somehow become easier: after strong shocks people lead themselves better".
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 164

title: Sergei Eisenstein listens to Vsevolod Vishnevski's first reading of the screenplay 'We, the Russian People'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein listens to Vsevolod Vishnevski's first reading of the screenplay 'We, the Russian People'; the next day he suggests that they work together on a film adaptation.

title: The director of Mosfilm wants Sergei Eisenstein to direct 'Rus (Aleksandr Nevski)'
description: Sergei Eisenstein stays at the spa in Kislovodsk. Sofia Sokolovskaia, director of Mosfilm, writes to Sergei Eisenstein on May 18 that she is trying to get him the contract to direct the film 'Rus' (working title for 'Aleksandr Nevski'). The script is currently being written by Petr Pavlenko.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 164

title: Sergei Eisenstein makes the acquaintance of Petr Pavlenko and begins work on the study 'Montage'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein returns to Moscow. Acquaintance with Petr Pavlenko. Sergei Eisenstein starts working on the study 'Montage'.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 164; updated according to information by Naum Kleiman

title: Sergei Eisenstein drafts sketches for the film project 'Spain'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein drafts sketches for the film project 'Spain'.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 164

title: Sergei Eisenstein works with Petr Pavlenko on the second version of the script of 'Rus'.
description: Petr Pavlenko finishes the first version of the script 'Rus', in which the content is given, but the detailed development of the plot is not yet executed. A few days later Sergei Eisenstein works with him on the second version.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 164

title: Sergei Eisenstein makes the final decision to direct 'Aleksandr Nevski'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein notes the final decision to direct 'Aleksandr Nevski'. He initially concentrates again on the study of historical materials. In doing so, he is confronted with the fundamental problem of historical film: to present the ideas, behavior and customs of a long past epoch in such a way that they arouse the interest of the viewer without distorting historic events. Studying old chronicles, he observes that the spirit of the events of the 13th century speaks of the same feeling that moved the people of his time and in this connection he discovers an almost literal correspondence between a newspaper report on the destruction of Guernica and a historical account of the destruction of Pskov. Another problem, the depiction of 13th-century man, is solved when visiting a church in Pereslavl-Zalesski. From a commemorative plaque Sergei Eisenstein deduces that the church was built in a few months. For him this changes at a stroke the relationship with the stone columns, arches and ceilings: they now suddenly spoke to him as living witnesses of human labour. From them shone the image of creative work as an element of life. In this way Eisenstein also solves the most important task of freeing Aleksandr Nevski's "holiness" from its religious glory and reducing it to its core. He defines the attribute "the saint" as "the highest form of esteem". Thus the historical consideration of our current theme has also made the hero appear as the man he was: as the only victor Nevski possessed by the great idea of power and independence of the homeland.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 164 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein starts an essay on the screenplay 'We, the Russian People', which he plans to adapt into a film.
description: Sergei Eisenstein starts an essay on the screenplay 'We, the Russian People', which he plans to adapt into a film
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 165 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein to Vsevolod Vishnevski about the work on 'Rus'
description: Sergei Eisenstein to Vsevolod Vishnevski: "I am extremely satisfied with Petr Pavlenko, both as an author and as a person. Soon we will set out on the Novgorod - Pskov - Lake Peipus - Vladimir route. The outlines of the film are very satisfying."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 166

title: Sergei Eisenstein on the study 'El Greco y el Cine'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein works on the study 'El Greco y el Cine', an appendix to the book 'Montage'; revised in May 1939.
works: El Greco y el Cine;Montage in 1938
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 166

title: Sergei Eisenstein works with Petr Pavlenko on the third screenplay version of 'Rus'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein works with Petr Pavlenko on the third screenplay version of 'Rus'. For several days they brood over the problem of finding a "Newtonian apple" on the plan to squeeze the "iron wedge of the crusaders like in a pair of pliers. Sergei Eisenstein finds the solution: on the eve of the battle Aleksandr should hear the fairy tale of the fox and the hare. The striking dynamics of the situation described here was the final impetus for Aleksandr to position his forces in this way and not otherwise.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 166

title: After another technical revision of 'Rus', the third version is sent to the GUK.
description: After another technical revision, the third version of 'Rus' is sent to the GUK. In its reply GUK recommends to emphasize the role of the people, peasants and craftsmen. Furthermore, the scenario should be freed from historical ballast and the people's victory over the Western conquerors should be more clearly emphasized. The conclusion provided in the script is deleted without replacement.
additional: GUK (Head Office of the Soviet Film Industry);Script
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 166

title: The scenario for 'Rus' is put into print by the magazine Znamya with Petr Pavlenko as author, Sergei Eisenstein as co-author.
description: The scenario is put into print by the magazine 'Znamya'. Petr Pavlenko is named as author, Sergei Eisenstein as co-author. Vladimir Lugovskoi, a member of the editorial staff, agrees to write the lyrics for the film. Sergei Eisenstein asks Sergei Prokofiev to compose the film music for 'Aleksandr Nevski'. Prokofiev postpones the decision until after his American tour.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 166 f.

title: The GUK releases the scenario 'Rus'.
description: The GUK releases the scenario 'Rus' for the development of the director's screenplay.

title: Boris Shumiatski is deposed as head of the Film Headquarters and banished to the province.
description: Boris Shumiatski is deposed as head of the Film Headquarters and banished to the province.
additional: GUK (Head Office of the Soviet Film Industry)
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 167

title: The scenario of 'Rus' is discussed at a conference with historians and scholars of history.
description: In Moscow the scenario 'Rus' is discussed at a conference with historians and scholars of history. Sergei Eisenstein speaks about the historical theme of the film and the necessity to deviate from historical facts in favor of an artistic generalization. Through the conference, Sergei Eisenstein is encouraged to rework the director's screenplay.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 167

title: Sergei Eisenstein visits Novgorod in search of filming locations for 'Rus'.
description: In search of locations, Sergei Eisenstein visits Novgorod. In a letter to Vsevolod Vishnevski he writes: "Almost nothing has been preserved; impossible to film here. There are still remains of the original architecture, but they have sunk so far into the earth that their proportions have been destroyed. At Lake Ilmen, Sergei Eisenstein makes notes "On the effects that can be achieved with the gigantic ice surfaces and snowfields".
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 167

title: Sergei Eisenstein, Eduard Tisse and Dmitri Vasilev create several versions of the director's screenplay.
description: Sergei Eisenstein, Eduard Tisse and Dmitri Vasilev create several versions of the director's screenplay of 'Rus'.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 167

title: Test shootings of 'Aleksandr Nevski' are made with artificial ice.
description: At Dmitri Vasilev's suggestion, test shootings of 'Aleksandr Nevski' are made with artificial ice.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 167

title: Sergei Eisenstein works on the theoretical article 'Montage in 1938'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein works on the theoretical article 'Montage in 1938': "There was a period in our cinematic art in which montage was 'everything'. Now a period is coming to an end in which montage 'nothing' applies. We do not adhere to either of these two extremes. After the campaign "for the montage" and the storm "against the montage", it is time to approach the problems of montage anew and without prejudice. The essay appears in 1939 and is revised in 1941 for the second publication.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 167 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein collects historical material and seeks shooting locations for outdoor shots for 'Aleksandr Nevski'.
description: In Pereslavl-Zalesski, Sergei Eisenstein collects historical material and seeks shooting locations for outdoor shots.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 168

title: Sergei Eisenstein begins working with Prokofiev on the film music for 'Aleksandr Nevski'.
description: Beginning of the collaboration with Sergei Prokofiev, who rejects Sergei Eisenstein's planned reconstruction of 13th-century chants, because the music has become so emotionally foreign to us that it is no longer able to feed the viewer's imagination. When recording music, Prokofiev experimented with new recording methods that exploited the shortcomings of technology to produce dramatic effects. Sergei Eisenstein and Prokofiev discuss the character of the music of the episode of the 'Battle of the Ice Lake', to which Sergei Eisenstein wants Prokofiev's music before the recordings begin. Eisenstein presents Prokofiev with the cadres he had drawn for the film, including Aleksandr Nevski on the Crow's Rock, the Russian warriors, the overall plan of their arrangement, the plan of the wedge-shaped arrangement of the infantry and the Crusaders, etc. At the same time, he told how he thought of 'The Battle of Ice Lake' in the montage.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 168 f.

title: Start of shooting of 'Aleksandr Nevski' in the studios of Mosfilm and in Pereslavl-Zalesski.
description: Start of shooting of 'Aleksandr Nevski' in the studios of Mosfilm and in Pereslavl-Zalesski. The team sets the deadline of November 7. Sergei Eisenstein: "It seemed to us completely impossible to achieve in such a short time an organic fusion of music and image and a strict internal correspondence between the visual and musical images, which is basically the whole secret of the sound film".
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 169 f.

title: Shooting for 'The Battle of the Ice'.
description: Shooting for 'The Battle of the Ice' on a field covered with chalk, sawdust and naphthalene near the Mosfilm studios. "We did not try to make the audience believe that the details of the Russian winter were real. Rather, we limited ourselves to the reproduction of the sound and colour proportions of winter: white background under a dark cloudy sky. But we did more than that: we never lost sight of the character of the film, we did not play the winter, but the battle. Winter only appeared as far as it seemed real. The secret of our success lies in this description, in this reduction of the winter elements to the most essential. Part of the effect of this sequence is attributed to Eduard Tisse's camera work: "The devil may know with what sophisticated technical tricks, but always clearly perceptible, Tisse sometimes achieves an almost astonishingly real colour illusion."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 170 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein works on the editing of 'Aleksandr Nevski'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein works on the editing of 'Aleksandr Nevski'. For the first time Sergei Eisenstein deals extensively with the montage of optical and acoustic pictograms in practice. He develops a principle which he later calls vertical montage, a further development of the polyphonic structure according to which the supplication procession was mounted in 'The General Line'. In the montage, he attempts to bring the horizontal lines of the optical and acoustic drawing section, which in their individual parts interact vertically and determine each other in their expressive quality, to a qualitatively new, organic unity. He defines it using the example of 'Battleship Potemkin': "A single, uniform law permeates not only the general whole and each of its individual parts, but also each area that has to participate in the creation of the whole.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 171-173

title: Via telegram Sergei Eisenstein announces the early completion of the film 'Aleksandr Nevski'.
description: In a telegram, Sergei Eisenstein announces with pleasure the early completion of the film for the 21st anniversary of the October Revolution.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 173

title: Aleksandr Nevski' is screened in the Mosfilm studio.
description: The finished film 'Aleksandr Nevski' is screened in the Mosfilm studio.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 173

title: Aleksandr Nevski' is released for public screening.

title: Sergei Eisenstein asks for three to four more working days for the montage of a boxing match scene on the Novgorod bridge.
description: Sergei Eisenstein asks for three to four more working days for the montage of a boxing match scene on the Novgorod bridge. This already shot sequence does not appear in the released version.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 173 f.

title: World premiere of 'Aleksandr Nevski' at the House of Film.
description: World premiere of 'Aleksandr Nevski' at the House of Film. In the introductory speech Sergei Eisenstein thanks Joseph Stalin for his support in the production of the film. With this film, Sergei Eisenstein restores his long-doubted reputation as a responsible Soviet film artist. Because of the patriotic theme and Sergei Eisenstein 's largely renunciation of cinematographic experiments, 'Aleksandr Nevski' is very popular with the Russian film public. Eisenstein's directorial achievement was not as undisputed as one might conclude from the subsequent official honors. Aleksandr Dovzhenko formulated his criticism at the conference convened in February 1940 on questions of historical and historical-revolutionary film. According to Dovzhenko Eisenstein had fallen into the captivity of painting. In the Federal Republic of Germany 'Aleksandr Nevski' remained almost unknown. The first review appears in 1952 and, apart from complete ignorance of artistic intentions, is nothing more than a vile defamation in the terminology of the Cold War. It was not until 1966, after 'Ivan the Terrible II' had already started, that a distributor succeeded in getting the film through the censorship without any cuts. This first complete screening after 28 years was registered only reluctantly by the critics; among the few existing reviews, most of which offer only summaries or absurd interpretations, only one of them reveals an examination of Eisenstein's film theoretical concept. After 'Aleksandr Nevski' had once passed through the cinema chains, he disappeared again in the archives and can be seen today only in seminar screenings.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 174-177

title: Sergei Eisenstein works on the essay 'On the Structure of Things'.

title: Sergei Eisenstein works on the production of 'Die Walküre'.
description: In the Bolshoi Theatre Sergei Eisenstein works on the production of 'Die Walküre'. He is fascinated by the task of bringing the pictorial elements of Richard Wagner's music onto the stage in a plastic and visual realization, in order to achieve an inner unity of visual and sound elements through the production. He sees here a further possibility to continue working on the fusion of image and sound as in 'Aleksandr Nevski'. For the first time he has the opportunity to work with the means of colour. In the last picture, 'Feuerzauber', he tries to unite the elements of Wagner's score with the changing coloured light effects on stage.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 179 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein works on a film adaptation about the Beilis Affair and 'Lawrence of Arabia'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is considering a film adaptation of the Beilis Affair according to Lev Sheinin; the Jew Beilis was accused of the ritual murder of a Christian boy. At the same time, Sergei Eisenstein is working on a project conceived as a colour film about Thomas Edward Lawrence, the 'Lawrence of Arabia', and a film about the plague - also in colour.
works: A film about Thomas E. Lawrence;Affaire Beilis (The Prestige of the Tsarist Empire)
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 180

title: Sergei Eisenstein draws conclusions from his historical studies of 'Ivan the Terrible' after the German army invaded the USSR.
description: After the German army invaded the USSR Sergei Eisenstein draws the following conclusions from his historical studies of Ivan the Terrible: The united and strong Moscow Empire, which came into being in the 16th century, came unexpectedly for the West. "Where did this Moscow Tsar and this strongest empire in the East suddenly come from?", the diplomats, humanists, princes and kings of the West asked themselves with concern. We, the people of Moscow in the 20th century, experience the same lack of understanding of the West.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 182 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein cites the short stories of Robert Louis Stevenson and Ambrose Bierce.
description: During a discussion at Mosfilm about the new film type of war film chronicle, Sergei Eisenstein cites the short stories of Robert Louis Stevenson and Ambrose Bierce as models for their structural composition.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 183

title: Journal entry on 'Ivan the Terrible'.
description: Eisenstein writes in the diary on the dramaturgy of 'Ivan the Terrible': "The theme of autocracy is solved in two aspects: One as autocrat + and + One as loner. The first brings the theme of state power (a progressive one in the given historical stage) – the political theme of the film. The second is the personal theme - the psychological theme of the film. Herein lies the compositional unity of the personal and the social, of the psychological, logical and political."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 186

title: Works on the design of different masks for the actor of Ivan.
description: Sergei Eisenstein works on the design of the different masks with the make-up artist Vasili Goriunov and the performer of the Ivan, Nikolai Cherkassov. Sergei Eisenstein pays special attention to the mask of Ivan, because the 39-year-old Cherkassov must be credible in all age classes of the tsar - from 17 to 54 years - over the course of the film. To reach this goal, 16 masks are designed for Cherkassov's face alone.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 186 f.

title: Sergei Eisenstein considers the participation of the ballerina Galina Ulanova in 'Ivan the Terrible'.
description: For a time Sergei Eisenstein is considering the participation of the ballerina Galina Ulanova in 'Ivan the Terrible'. He visits her after a performance in Alma-Ata. She agrees to trial runs, but has fights with Sergei Eisenstein concerning the constrictions of the historic outfit. When they agreed and rehearsals should start, it was already 1943 and Ulanova couldn't commit for a long shooting period and cancelled.
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;pp. 187-189

description: In Germany, 'Ivan the Terrible' will initially only be shown in the screenings of the film clubs and will not be released in public cinemas until after the successful re-release of the second part. In 1958, the film was still being measured with the ideological yardstick and an absurd separation of content and form was attempted.

title: Sergei Eisenstein attends a party given for the awarding of the Stalin Prize and has a cardiac infarction.
description: Right after finishing the montage of 'Ivan the Terrible II', Sergei Eisenstein attends a party given for the awarding of the Stalin Prize. While dancing he collapses with a cardiac infarction and is admitted to the Kremlin hospital. "By an incomprehensibly nonsensical anduseless miracle I stayed alive. According to all the laws of science I should have died [...] Therefore I consider everything that happens now as a postscript to my own life story ...".

source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 197

description: Sergei Eisenstein writes the 'First Letter on Colour'; he opposes naturalistic colouring and points out that colour must be subject to the same laws as montage, music and composition.

title: Sergei Eisenstein writes the 'Second Letter on Colour'.
description: Writes the 'Second Letter on Colour' about his previous experiments and future projects in the field of colour film.

title: Publication of the Central Committee's criticism on 'Ivan the Terrible II'.
description: Publication of the Central Committee's decision on 'Ivan the Terrible II': "Sergei Eisenstein proved his complete ignorance of the historical facts by depicting the progressive army of Oprichniki as a degenerate gang of the type of the American Ku Klux Clan, and Ivan himself a personality of strong will and character, as his figure similar to Hamlet, without will and with weak character."
source: Sudendorf;Werner (1975): 'Sergej M. Eisenstein – Materialien zu Leben und Werk'. München/Wien: Carl Hanser Verlag;p. 197

title: Sergei Eisenstein writes the article 'The True Paths of Discovery'.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes the article 'The True Paths of Discovery', in which he examines the dramaturgical problem, using the example of 'Aleksandr Nevski', "of demonstrating in the fate of the characters and in the play of the actors a thesis, a paragraph, formulated in advance, instead of [...] letting it [...] crystallize out of the basic idea - at the same time as it is intensified in the course of the play - [...] which then becomes the most striking expressive factor of the basic thematic idea: the idea that determines the work."

title: Sergei Eisenstein suffers another heart attack whilst writing.
description: Sergei Eisenstein writes a sketch for the 'Ivan the Terrible' project. While writing, Sergei Eisenstein suffers another heart attack. The black pencil with which Sergei Eisenstein writes slips over the paper until the words "Motherland" are written. After Sergei Eisenstein has obviously taken a medicine, he notes with a red pencil: "At that moment I had a heart attack. Here is the trace in the handwriting. 10. 2. 48." Sergei Eisenstein continues to work and writes two more pages. There are also dated notes from February 10th about an investigation on 'Pushkin and Gogol'.
category: Biography and Personality;Cinema and Theatre;Writing and Teaching
